[2] If continuous GND cannot be implemented, a combination of GND on one side and continuous power plane on the other side with the condition that the GND plane be the closer reference (dual-reference) can be implemented. The continuous power plane requires low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt). [3] If non-continuous power referencing is required on microstrip/ surface layer, signal can reference over power planes with a low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt).

[For Internal Validation] ISH-SPI 1-Load (Add-In Card with Cable) Topology

Description: This is a request from RVP to support 1-Load over cabling topology with operating frequency max 16 MHz

ISH-SPI 1-Load (Add-In Card + Cable) Topology Diagram
[For Internal Validation] ISH-SPI 1-Load (Add-In Card with Cable) Topology Notes
NoteDetail
Reference plane[1] Continuous GND is recommended. [2] If continuous GND cannot be implemented, a combination of GND on one side and continuous power plane on the other side with the condition that the GND plane be the closer reference (dual-reference) can be implemented. The continuous power plane requires low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt). [3] If non-continuous power referencing is required on microstrip/ surface layer, signal can reference over power planes with a low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt).
Max frequency16 MHz
Device AC timing characteristicsData input setup time < 5 ns. Data input hold time < 5 ns. 1 ns < CLK to DATA output valid time < 15 ns.
R10 Ω placeholder. To be placed on ISH_SPI_CLK, ISH_SPIA_CLK, ISH_SPI_MOSI and ISH_SPIA_MOSI.
R20 Ω placeholder. To be placed on ISH_SPI_MISO and ISH_SPIA_MISO.
Cable electrical characteristics-0.075 dB/inch < Insertion loss < -0.052 dB/inch -32.8 dB < Return loss < -46.2 dB -45.4 dB < Crosstalk < -47.2 dB 42 Ω < Impedance < 62 Ω
Length matching between CLK and DATA signals12.7 mm
Trace spacing between DATA and DATA signals0.125 mm
Trace spacing between CLK and DATA/ other signals0.375 mm
Processor buffer drive strength50 Ω
Signal name/ listISH_SPI_CLK, ISH_SPI_MISO, ISH_SPI_MOSI, ISH_SPI_CS#, ISH_SPIA_CLK, ISH_SPIA_MISO, ISH_SPIA_MOSI, ISH_SPIA_CS#.

DEVICEDevice17-1

BOMS, DSL, SL12.7

CableCable304.8

Min Length Total (mm): 76.2

Max Length Total (mm): 635

Max Length Total Note: Total length of 635 mm can be supported with bus frequency needs to limit to 16 MHz.

Imaging Clock

Imaging Clock 1-Load (Add-In Card) Topology

Imaging Clock 1-Load (Add-In Card) Topology Diagram
Imaging Clock 1-Load (Add-In Card) Topology Notes
NoteDetail
Device duty cycle specInput clock duty cycle spec of ± 10% or above (example: ± 15%). Refer to vendor's datasheet for the device electrical spec. If the information is not published in the device datasheet, do contact the device vendor for more details.
Reference plane[1] Continuous GND is recommended. [2] If continuous GND cannot be implemented, a combination of GND on one side and continuous power plane on the other side with the condition that the GND plane be the closer reference (dual-reference) can be implemented. The continuous power plane requires low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt). [3] If non-continuous power referencing is required on microstrip/ surface layer, signal can reference over power planes with a low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt).
R110 Ω ± 5%. Recommended to be placed 25.4 mm from the processor.
Max Length SegmentMax segment length for M1, M2 and M_cable are interchangeable as long as total max length M1 + M2 + M_cable is < 393.7 mm.
Trace spacing between CLK and other signals0.375 mm
Processor buffer driver strength33 Ω.
Signal name/ listIMGCLKOUT[0:2].
Max Number of vias
Signal GroupMax Number of Vias AllowedVia Placement
Tx3Total Channel

Signal Group: Tx

Signal MRTS
Segment NameCategoryStartEnd
CPUDevice01
BOTrace12
R1Resistor23
M1Trace34

LSX

LSX 1-Load to Retimer (Device Down) Topology

LSX 1-Load to Retimer (Device Down) Topology Diagram
LSX 1-Load to Retimer (Device Down) Topology Notes
NoteDetail
Trace spacing between DATA and DATA/ others signals0.125 mm
Reference plane[1] Continuous GND is recommended. [2] If continuous GND cannot be implemented, a combination of GND on one side and continuous power plane on the other side with the condition that the GND plane be the closer reference (dual-reference) can be implemented. The continuous power plane requires low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt). [3] If non-continuous power referencing is required on microstrip/ surface layer, signal can reference over power planes with a low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt).
Processor buffer driver strength50 Ω.
Signal name/ listTBT_LSX[0:2]_TXD, TBT_LSX[0:2]_RXD.

CPUDevice01

Processor GPIO

Processor GPIO CMOS Buffer Type Topology

Processor GPIO 1-Load Topology Diagram
Processor GPIO Multi-Load Branch Topology Diagram
Formula for Strapping or Pull-up Resistor Calculation
Example of Strapping or Pull-up Resistor Calculation
Processor GPIO CMOS Buffer Type Topology Notes
NoteDetail
Total trace lengthTotal trace length options as below: [1] Total trace length BO + M1 + BI =< 177.8 mm, or [2] Total trace length BO + M2 + BI =< 177.8 mm, or [3] Total trace length BO + Mn + BI =< 177.8 mm.
Strapping resistor, R_strap20 kΩ on need basis, for strapping purposes. Resistor can be either pull-up or pull-down depending on strapping design.
Number of vias allowedNo restriction.
Reference planeNo restriction.
Note 1R_strap resistor is optional depending on signal needs and can be anywhere along M1, M2, Mn lane. Refer to EDS or device datasheet for the requirement.
Note 2Main route of Mn can start anywhere along M1 as long as the total length of each branch from processor to device is less than 177.8 mm.
Note 3R_strap resistor value depends on power sequence/ strapping's timing and DC voltage level requirement (refer below for calculation details).
Note 4Level shifter may be needed depending on actual device implementation. Generally no length restriction after level shifter.
Note 5For processor input-only signal, if device output is open drain buffer type, then proper pull-up resistor, Rpu is needed and refer to "Rise Time and R_strap or Rpu Calculation" section for details.
Note 6Noise sensitive GPIO pin should be properly shielded/ with sufficient trace spacing (e.g.: 3x of trace width). This is to prevent undesirable random system reset.
Rise time and R_strap or Rpu calculation
R_strap or Rpu formulaRefer image [Formula for Strapping or Pull-up Resistor].
Bus capacitance rule of thumb, CbDevice = 10 pF per device. Board trace = 3.3 pF per 25.4 mm of trace length.
Example[1] Total bus length = 10 inches --> 10 x 3.3 pF = 33 pF. [2] Branch topology with two devices --> 2 x 10 pF = 20 pF. [3] With a rise time requirement (tr) = 1 us. Refer image [Example for Strapping or Pull-up Resistor Calculation].

Segment Lengths

Processor GPIO CMOS Buffer Type Topology Segment Lengths Routing Guidelines
SegmentTline TypeMax Length Segment (mm)
BOMS, DSL, SL12.7
M1MS, DSL, SL177.6
BIMS, DSL, SL12.7

Max Length Total (mm): 203

[For Internal Reference] Processor GPIO Open Drain Buffer Type Topology

Description: Note: For internal reference only! Do not publish in external PDG!

Formula for Strapping or Pull-up Resistor Calculation
Example for Strapping or Pull-up Resistor Calculation
[For Internal Reference] Processor GPIO Open Drain Buffer Type Topology Notes
NoteDetail
Note 1No length/ topology restriction.
Note 2Pull-up resistor, Rpu can be calculated based on rise time requirement (refer to "Rise time and R_strap or Rpu calculation" section for details). Rise time requirement may varies depending on device requirement (if any), refer to device data sheet.
Note 3Intel input buffer does not have any rise/ fall time requirement. For device TX open drain signal, refer to device's design guide or Intel reference schematic for pull-up resistor value.
Rise time and R_strap or Rpu calculation
R_strap or Rpu formulaRefer image [Formula for Strapping or Pull-up Resistor].
Bus capacitance rule of thumb, CbDevice = 10 pF per device. Board trace = 3.3 pF per 25.4 mm of trace length.
Example[1] Total bus length = 10 inches --> 10 x 3.3 pF = 33 pF. [2] Branch topology with two devices --> 2 x 10 pF = 20 pF. [3] With a rise time requirement (tr) = 1 us. Refer image [Example for Strapping or Pull-up Resistor Calculation].

SMLink

SMLink General Guidelines
NoteDetail
Note 1Multiple options for pull-up/ pull-down and current assist strengths are provided for a particular total bus capacitance. Choose the optimal value for system based on design considerations like power, BOM and cost.
Note 2Trace capacitance per inch is approximately CL = 85√єr / Zo pF, єr - dielectric constant of material, Zo - trace impedance.
Note 3Bus capacitance calculation assumptions: [1] Device capacitance = 5 pF to 10 pF per SMLink device. [2] Motherboard board trace capacitance = 2 pF to 5 pF per inch of trace length. [3] Processor pin capacitance = 8 pF to 10 pF.

SMLink Topology

SMLink Topology Notes
NoteDetail
Stackup layer (microstrip/ stripline/ dual stripline)MS/ SL/ DSL.
Characteristic impedance30 Ω to 70 Ω.
Reference plane[1] Continuous GND is recommended. [2] If continuous GND cannot be implemented, a combination of GND on one side and continuous power plane on the other side with the condition that the GND plane be the closer reference (dual-reference) can be implemented. The continuous power plane requires low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt). [3] If non-continuous power referencing is required on microstrip/ surface layer, signal can reference over power planes with a low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt).
Trace spacing between CLK and other signals [1] 0.375 mm: Frequency of other signals > 1 GHz. [2] 0.250 mm: Frequency of other signals > 100 MHz. [3] 0.125 mm: Frequency of other signals ≤ 100 MHz.
Trace spacing between DATA and other signals0.125 mm
Trace segment lengthRefer to bus capacitance table.
Total trace length (DATA, CLK)Individual trace lengths should meet total bus capacitance (Cb) requirements for the mode of operation. Refer to the pull-up/ pull-down tables for the supported bus capacitance.
Length matching between DATA and CLK signals25.4 mm
Pull-up resistor placementNo restriction.
Pull-up resistor value tolerance± 5%
Max stub length to pull-up resistor25.4 mm
Board trace characteristic assumptions for default pull-up recommendationBoard trace resistance per length = 20 Ω per meter. Board trace capacitance per length = 208 pF per meter.
Extended length supportFor extended length support, refer to "xxxxxx_NVL-H_I2C_SMLINK_LSIO_Flexi_PDG". Potential enablers: [1] Reduced trace resistance. [2] Reduced trace capacitance. [3] Optimized pull-up resistor placement.
Signal name/ listSML[0:1]CLK, SML[0:1]DATA, SML[0:1]ALERT#, SML0BCLK, SML0BDATA, SML0BALERT#, PSE_SMLCLK, PSE_SMLDATA, PSE_SMLALERT#, USBC-SMLCLK, USBC-SMLDATA.

SMLink Standard Mode (100 kHz)

Frequency: 100 kHz

SMLink Standard Mode (100 kHz) Settings
Total Bus Capacitance (Cb)External Pull-up StrengthIntel Silicon Pull-down Strength
Up to 50 pF5.6 kΩ100 Ω
Up to 100 pF2.7 kΩ100 Ω
Up to 200 pF1.5 kΩ100 Ω
Up to 300 pF1 kΩ100 Ω
Up to 400 pF820 Ω100 Ω

SMLink Fast Mode (400 kHz)

Frequency: 400 kHz

SMLink Fast Mode (400 kHz) Settings
Total Bus Capacitance (Cb)External Pull-up StrengthIntel Silicon Pull-down Strength
Up to 50 pF1.8 kΩ100 Ω
Up to 100 pF1.5 kΩ100 Ω
75pF to 200 pF560 Ω100 Ω
85 pF to 300 pF430 Ω50 Ω

SMLink Fast Mode Plus (1 MHz)

Frequency: 1 MHz

SMLink Fast Mode Plus (1 MHz) Settings
Total Bus Capacitance (Cb)External Pull-up StrengthIntel Silicon Pull-down Strength
Up to 50 pF820 Ω100 Ω
Up to 100 pF470 Ω100 Ω
Up to 200 pF270 Ω50 Ω

SoundWire

SoundWire Large System: 1-Load (Add-In Card) Topology

SoundWire Large System: 1-Load (Add-In Card) Topology Diagram
SoundWire Large System: 1-Load (Add-In Card) Topology Notes
NoteDetail
M_Cable characteristic impedance target50 Ω ± 10%.
Reference plane[1] Continuous GND is recommended. [2] If continuous GND cannot be implemented, a combination of GND on one side and continuous power plane on the other side with the condition that the GND plane be the closer reference (dual-reference) can be implemented. The continuous power plane requires low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt). [3] If non-continuous power referencing is required on microstrip/ surface layer, signal can reference over power planes with a low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt).
Max frequency12.288 MHz
SoundWire ports supportedSingle-lane: Port #0, Port #1, Port #2, Port #3. Multi-lane: Port #2 (up to 3 data lane), Port #3 (up to 4 data lane).
Length matching between CLK and DATA signals5.08 mm
Processor TX & RX timing register configurationFor total length < 600 mm: [1] CLDS = 5 Clock Period [2] DODS/DODSE/DODSE2 = 7 Clock Period [3] DOAIS/DOAISE/DOAISE2 = 9 Clock Period For total length ≥ 600 mm: [1] CLDS = 6 Clock Period [2] DODS/DODSE/DODSE2 = 7 Clock Period [3] DOAIS/DOAISE/DOAISE2 = 9 Clock Period Please refer to "Intel Smart Sound Technology ACPI Configuration" for further details on how to configure timing register. (BIOS Specification Doc#:  609917)
Processor buffer driver strength50 Ω, slew 11.
Device buffer driver strength & resistor combination1) Device buffer driver strength of 20 Ω ± 30% 2) Device series resistor of 56 Ω ± 5% Refer to section on "Additional Guidelines - SoundWire* Interface Design Guidelines" for resistor placement to achieve the recommended device drive impedance target.
Signal name/ listSingle-lane: SNDW[0:3]_CLK, SNDW[0:3]_DATA0. Multi-lane: SNDW[2:3]_CLK, SNDW2_DATA[0:2], SNDW3_DATA[0:3], SNDW2A_DATA1.
Max Number of vias
Signal GroupMax Number of Vias AllowedVia Placement
Rx, Tx4Total Channel

Signal Group: Rx-Tx

Signal MRTS
Segment NameCategoryStartEnd
TXDevice01
BOTrace12
M1Trace23
M2Trace34
CONNDevice4-1

NoteDetail
M_Cable characteristic impedance target50 Ω ± 10%.
R10 Ω placeholder. To be placed 10 mm to 15 mm from the branch.
R20 Ω placeholder. To be placed 5 mm to 10 mm after the branch.
Reference plane[1] Continuous GND is recommended. [2] If continuous GND cannot be implemented, a combination of GND on one side and continuous power plane on the other side with the condition that the GND plane be the closer reference (dual-reference) can be implemented. The continuous power plane requires low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt). [3] If non-continuous power referencing is required on microstrip/ surface layer, signal can reference over power planes with a low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt).
Length matching between branch for Device 1 & 2 (Option 1: M_cable or Option 2: M4)10 mm
Max frequency9.6 MHz

Length matching between CLK and DATA signals5.08 mm
Processor TX & RX timing register configurationFor total length < 850. 9 mm: [1] CLDS = 5 Clock Period [2] DODS/DODSE/DODSE2 = 10 Clock Period [3] DOAIS/DOAISE/DOAISE2 = 10 Clock Period For total length ≥ 850.9 mm: [1] CLDS = 9 Clock Period [2] DODS/DODSE/DODSE2 = 10 Clock Period [3] DOAIS/DOAISE/DOAISE2 = 10 Clock Period Please refer to "Intel Smart Sound Technology ACPI Configuration" for further details on how to configure timing register. The continuous power plane requires low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt). [3] If non-continuous power referencing is required on microstrip/ surface layer, signal can reference over power planes with a low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt).

SoundWire Large System: 2-Load Dumbbell Topology

SoundWire Large System: 2-Load Dumbbell (Device Down) Topology Diagram
SoundWire Large System: 2-Load Dumbbell (Add-In Card) Topology Diagram
SoundWire Large System: 2-Load Dumbbell Topology Notes
NoteDetail
M_Cable1 characteristic impedance target50 Ω ± 10%.
R1Device Down topology: 10 Ω ± 10%. To be placed on SNDW_CLK only, and 10 mm from the branching. Add-In Card topology: 22 Ω ± 10%. To be placed on SNDW_CLK only, and 10 mm from the branching.
R2Device Down topology: 10 Ω ± 10%. To be placed on SNDW_CLK only, and 10 mm from the branching. Add-In Card topology: 22 Ω ± 10%. To be placed on SNDW_CLK only, and 10 mm from the branching.
Reference plane[1] Continuous GND is recommended. [2] If continuous GND cannot be implemented, a combination of GND on one side and continuous power plane on the other side with the condition that the GND plane be the closer reference (dual-reference) can be implemented. The continuous power plane requires low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt). [3] If non-continuous power referencing is required on microstrip/ surface layer, signal can reference over power planes with a low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt).
Max frequency9.6 MHz

(BIOS Specification Doc#:  609917)

SoundWire Large System: 3 to 4-Load Dumbbell Topology

SoundWire Large System: 3 to 4-Load Dumbbell Topology Notes
NoteDetail
M_Cable_[1:2] characteristic impedance target50 Ω ± 10%.
R115 Ω ± 10%. To be placed on SNDW_CLK only, and 10 mm from the branching.
R215 Ω ± 10%. To be placed on SNDW_CLK only, and 10 mm from the branching.
Multiload supportThis topology supports up to 4 devices. For 3-Load topology, only device 2/ 3/ 4 can be removed.
Length ExtensionTotal length for 3-Load topology can be extended up to 520 mm by increase segment length: [1] M4 + M_cable1 = 300 mm [2] M5 = 300 mm
Reference plane[1] Continuous GND is recommended. [2] If continuous GND cannot be implemented, a combination of GND on one side and continuous power plane on the other side with the condition that the GND plane be the closer reference (dual-reference) can be implemented. The continuous power plane requires low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt). [3] If non-continuous power referencing is required on microstrip/ surface layer, signal can reference over power planes with a low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt).
Max frequency9.6 MHz
SoundWire ports supportedPort #0, Port #1, Port #2, Port #3.
Length matching between CLK and DATA signals5.08 mm
Processor TX & RX timing register configurationFor total length < 508 mm: [1] CLDS = 5 Clock Period [2] DODS/DODSE/DODSE2 = 10 Clock Period [3] DOAIS/DOAISE/DOAISE2 = 10 Clock Period For total length ≥ 508 mm: [1] CLDS = 9 Clock Period [2] DODS/DODSE/DODSE2 = 10 Clock Period [3] DOAIS/DOAISE/DOAISE2 = 10 Clock Period Please refer to "Intel Smart Sound Technology ACPI Configuration" for further details on how to configure timing register. (BIOS Specification Doc#:  609917)
Processor buffer driver strength50 Ω, slew 11.
Device buffer driver strength & resistor combination1) Device buffer driver strength of 20 Ω ± 30% 2) Device series resistor of 91 Ω ± 5% Refer to section on "Additional Guidelines - SoundWire* Interface Design Guidelines" for resistor placement to achieve the recommended device drive impedance target.

BOMS, DSL, SL12.7
M1MS, DSL, SL137.3
M2_1MS, DSL, SL10
M2_2MS, DSL, SL10
M3MS, DSL, SL150
M5MS, DSL, SL200
M6MS, DSL, SL50
M7MS, DSL, SL30
M8_1MS, DSL, SL30
M8_2MS, DSL, SL30
M9MS, DSL, SL100
M10MS, DSL, SL250
M4 + M_Cable1MS, DSL, SL, Cable200
M_Cable2Cable50
M_Cable3Cable30
M_Cable4_1Cable30
M_Cable4_2Cable30

Min Length Total (mm): 127

Max Length Total (mm): 420

Max Length Total Note: 1) Max length between processor to the furthest end device = 420 mm;​ 2) Total topology length = 760 mm.

SoundWire Large System: 1 to 4-Load Daisy Chain Topology

SoundWire Large System: 1 to 4-Load Daisy Chain Topology Diagram
SoundWire Large System: 1 to 4-Load Daisy Chain Topology Notes
NoteDetail
M_Cable_[1:4] characteristic impedance target50 Ω ± 10%.
R10 Ω placeholder. To be placed on SNDW_CLK only, and maximum 10 mm from the connector.
Multiload supportThis topology supports up to 4 devices where device placements are interchangable.
M_Cable_1 maximum length250 mm
Max allowable cable length between nearest device and furthest device from processor300 mm
Reference plane[1] Continuous GND is recommended. [2] If continuous GND cannot be implemented, a combination of GND on one side and continuous power plane on the other side with the condition that the GND plane be the closer reference (dual-reference) can be implemented. The continuous power plane requires low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt). [3] If non-continuous power referencing is required on microstrip/ surface layer, signal can reference over power planes with a low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt).
Max frequency9.6 MHz
SoundWire ports supportedPort #0, Port #1, Port #2, Port #3.
Length matching between CLK and DATA signals5.08 mm
Processor TX & RX timing register configuration[1] CLDS = 5 Clock Period [2] DODS/DODSE/DODSE2 = 10 Clock Period [3] DOAIS/DOAISE/DOAISE2 = 10 Clock Period Please refer to "Intel Smart Sound Technology ACPI Configuration" for further details on how to configure timing register. (BIOS Specification Doc#:  609917)
Processor buffer driver strength50 Ω, slew 01.
Device buffer driver strength & resistor combination1) Device buffer driver strength of 20 Ω ± 30% 2) Device series resistor of 56 Ω ± 5% Refer to section on "Additional Guidelines - SoundWire* Interface Design Guidelines" for resistor placement to achieve the recommended device drive impedance target.
Signal name/ listSNDW[0:3]_CLK, SNDW[0:3]_DATA0.
Max Number of vias
Signal GroupMax Number of Vias AllowedVia Placement
Rx, Tx4Total Channel

Signal Group: Rx-Tx

Signal MRTS
Segment NameCategoryStartEnd
CPUDevice01
BOTrace12
M1Trace23
R1Resistor34
M2Trace45
CONNDevice5-1

SoundWire Large System: 3-Load Cable Stick (Add-In Card) Topology

SoundWire Large System: 3-Load Cable Stick (Add-In Card) Topology Diagram
SoundWire Large System: 3-Load Cable Stick (Add-In Card) Topology Notes
NoteDetail
M_Cable characteristic impedance target50 Ω ± 10%.
R10 Ω placeholder. To be placed on SNDW_CLK only, and maximum 10 mm from the connector.
Reference plane[1] Continuous GND is recommended. [2] If continuous GND cannot be implemented, a combination of GND on one side and continuous power plane on the other side with the condition that the GND plane be the closer reference (dual-reference) can be implemented. The continuous power plane requires low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt). [3] If non-continuous power referencing is required on microstrip/ surface layer, signal can reference over power planes with a low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt).
Max frequency9.6 MHz
SoundWire ports supportedPort #0, Port #1, Port #2, Port #3.
Length matching between CLK and DATA signals5.08 mm
Processor TX & RX timing register configurationFor total length < 850.9 mm: [1] CLDS = 5 Clock Period [2] DODS/DODSE/DODSE2 = 10 Clock Period [3] DOAIS/DOAISE/DOAISE2 = 10 Clock Period For total length ≥ 850.9 mm: [1] CLDS = 9 Clock Period [2] DODS/DODSE/DODSE2 = 10 Clock Period [3] DOAIS/DOAISE/DOAISE2 = 10 Clock Period Please refer to "Intel Smart Sound Technology ACPI Configuration" for further details on how to configure timing register. (BIOS Specification Doc#:  609917)
Processor buffer driver strength50 Ω, slew 01.
Device buffer driver strength & resistor combination1) Device buffer driver strength of 20 Ω ± 30% 2) Device series resistor of 56 Ω ± 5% Refer to section on "Additional Guidelines - SoundWire* Interface Design Guidelines" for resistor placement to achieve the recommended device drive impedance target.
Signal name/ listSNDW[0:3]_CLK, SNDW[0:3]_DATA0.

SoundWire Small System: 1 to 4-Load Daisy Chain (Device Down) Topology

SoundWire Small System: 1 to 4-Load Daisy Chain (Device Down) Topology Diagram
SoundWire Small System: 1 to 4-Load Daisy Chain (Device Down) Topology Notes
NoteDetail
Multiload supportThis topology supports up to 4 devices where device placements are interchangable.
Reference plane[1] Continuous GND is recommended. [2] If continuous GND cannot be implemented, a combination of GND on one side and continuous power plane on the other side with the condition that the GND plane be the closer reference (dual-reference) can be implemented. The continuous power plane requires low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt). [3] If non-continuous power referencing is required on microstrip/ surface layer, signal can reference over power planes with a low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt).
Max frequency12.288 MHz
SoundWire ports supported1 to 4-Load topology: Single-lane: Port #0, Port #1, Port #2, Port #3. 1-Load topology: Multi-lane: Port #2 (up to 3 data lane), Port #3 (up to 4 data lane).
Length matching between CLK and DATA signals5.08 mm
Processor TX & RX timing register configuration[1] CLDS = 5 Clock Period [2] DODS/DODSE/DODSE2 = 10 Clock Period [3] DOAIS/DOAISE/DOAISE2 = 10 Clock Period Please refer to "Intel Smart Sound Technology ACPI Configuration" for further details on how to configure timing register. (BIOS Specification Doc#:  609917)
Processor buffer driver strength50 Ω, slew 11.
Device buffer driver strength & resistor combination1) Device buffer driver strength of 20 Ω ± 30% 2) Device series resistor of 56 Ω ± 5% Refer to section on "Additional Guidelines - SoundWire* Interface Design Guidelines" for resistor placement to achieve the recommended device drive impedance target.
Signal name/ listSingle-lane: SNDW[0:3]_CLK, SNDW[0:3]_DATA0. Multi-lane: SNDW[2:3]_CLK, SNDW2_DATA[0:2], SNDW3_DATA[0:3], SNDW2A_DATA1.

[For Internal Validation] SoundWire Large System: 4-Load Star (AIC) Topology

SoundWire Large System: 4-Load Star (Add-In Card) Topology Diagram
[For Internal Validation] SoundWire Large System: 4-Load Star (AIC) Topology Notes
NoteDetail
M_Cable_1/ M_Cable_2 characteristic impedance target50 Ω ± 10%.
R10 Ω placeholder. To be placed 10 mm to 15 mm from the first branch from processor.
R20 Ω placeholder. To be placed 5 mm to 10 mm from the device.
Number of vias allowed4
Reference plane[1] Continuous GND is recommended. [2] If continuous GND cannot be implemented, a combination of GND on one side and continuous power plane on the other side with the condition that the GND plane be the closer reference (dual-reference) can be implemented. The continuous power plane requires low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt). [3] If non-continuous power referencing is required on microstrip/ surface layer, signal can reference over power planes with a low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt).
Max length, totalThis refers to the length from processor to the end device of each branch. [1] B0 + M1 + M2 + M3_1 + M_Cable_1 + M4_1_1 + M5_1_1; or [2] B0 + M1 + M2 + M3_1 + M_Cable_1 + M4_1_2 + M5_1_2; or [3] B0 + M1 + M2 + M3_2 + M_Cable_2 + M4_2_1 + M5_2_1; or [4] B0 + M1 + M2 + M3_2 + M_Cable_2 + M4_2_2 + M5_2_2.
Length matching between branch (M3_1 & M3_2)10 mm
Max frequency9.6 MHz
SoundWire ports supportedPort #0, Port #1, Port #2, Port #3.
Length matching between CLK and DATA signals5.08 mm
Processor TX & RX timing register configurationFor total length < 571.5 mm: [1] CLDS = 5 Clock Period [2] DODS/DODSE/DODSE2 = 10 Clock Period [3] DOAIS/DOAISE/DOAISE2 = 10 Clock Period For total length ≥ 571.5 mm: [1] CLDS = 9 Clock Period [2] DODS/DODSE/DODSE2 = 10 Clock Period [3] DOAIS/DOAISE/DOAISE2 = 10 Clock Period Please refer to "Intel Smart Sound Technology ACPI Configuration" for further details on how to configure timing register. (BIOS Specification Doc#:  609917)
Processor buffer driver strength50 Ω, slew 11.
Device buffer driver strength & resistor combination1) Device buffer driver strength of 20 Ω ± 30% 2) Device series resistor of 91 Ω ± 5% Refer to section on "Additional Guidelines - SoundWire* Interface Design Guidelines" for resistor placement to achieve the recommended device drive impedance target.
Signal name/ listSNDW[0:3]_CLK, SNDW[0:3]_DATA0.

[For Internal Validation] Additional Guidelines - SoundWire* Interface Design Guidelines

Description: In the topology section the device buffer strength target recommendations are different depending on the Topology and its configuration. If devices used do not have buffer strengths that match the target recommendations and do not have the ability to adjust the buffer strengths through software you can adjust the impedance via an external resistor (R1) in series near the device, between the device and processor. To determine R1 the formula is: R1=Device Buffer Impedance Target - Actual Device Buffer Impedance.

[For Internal Validation] SoundWire* Device Drive Impedance Adjustment Diagram
[For Internal Validation] Additional Guidelines - SoundWire* Interface Design Guidelines Notes
NoteDetail
M110 mm
R1R1 = Device Drive Impedance Target - Device Buffer Strength. For example: Device Drive Impedance Target = 80 Ω. Device Buffer Strength = 45 Ω. Then R1 = 80 Ω - 45 Ω = 35 Ω.

SPI0 Flash

SPI0 Flash 50MHz 1 to 4-Load Branch (Device Down) MAF Topology

SPI0 50MHz 1-Load MAF (Device Down) Topology Diagram
SPI0 50MHz 2-Load Branch MAF (Device Down) with 2 Flash Topology Diagram
SPI0 50MHz 2-Load Branch MAF (Device Down) with Flash and TPM Topology Diagram
SPI0 50MHz 3-Load Branch MAF (Device Down) Topology Diagram
SPI0 50MHz 4-Load Branch MAF (Device Down) Topology Diagram
SPI0 Flash 50MHz 1 to 4-Load Branch (Device Down) MAF Topology Notes
NoteDetail
Reference planeContinuous ground only.
Max frequencyFlash 1 & Flash 2: 50 MHz. TPM: 33 MHz.
Flash ProgrammerRequire additional isolation circuitry to protect processor from back-feed voltage when connect to flash programmer.
R124 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 5.08 mm from the branch on SPI0_CLK, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3.
R251 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 5.08 mm from the branch on SPI0_CLK, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3.
Length from processor to flash 1 or flash 2Length from processor to flash 1 or flash 2: = BO + M1 + M2 + M3
Flash device electrical characteristics recommendation for 50MHz support: Option 1[1] Driver strength spec: 50 Ω or stronger across worse case corners. [2] 0.4 ns ≤ rise/ fall time measured at 30% to 70% ≤ 1.45 ns based on 30 pF test load. [3] Output capacitance, Cout ≤ 16 pF (including RPMC die). [4] Input capacitance, Cin ≤ 12 pF (including RPMC die). [5] Data input setup time ≤ 3 ns. [6] Data input hold time ≤ 3 ns. [7] CLK to DATA output valid time, min: 1 ns, based on 30 pF test load. [8] CLK to DATA output valid time, max: 6.5 ns (50% to 50%), based on 30 pF test load.
Flash device electrical characteristics recommendation for 50MHz support: Option 2[1] Driver strength spec: 40 Ω or stronger across worse case corners. [2] 0.4 ns ≤ rise/ fall time measured at 30% to 70% ≤ 1.25 ns based on 30 pF test load. [3] Output capacitance, Cout ≤ 14 pF (including RPMC die). [4] Input capacitance, Cin ≤ 12 pF (including RPMC die). [5] Data input setup time ≤ 3 ns. [6] Data input hold time ≤ 3 ns. [7] CLK to DATA output valid time, min: 1 ns, based on 30 pF test load. [8] CLK to DATA output valid time, max: 9 ns (50% to 50%), based on 30 pF test load.
Stuffing resistorIf one of devices is unstuffed (rework), treat it as (n -1)-Load topology thus place stuffing resistor as close as possible to the branch to avoid long stub length.
Length matching between CLK and DATA/ CS# signals12.7 mm
Trace spacing between DATA and DATA signals0.250 mm
Trace spacing between CLK and DATA/ other signals0.375 mm
Signal name/ listSPI0_CLK, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_IO2, SPI0_IO3, SPI0_CS[0:1]# (for flash), SPI0_CS2# (for TPM)
Max Number of vias
Signal GroupMax Number of Vias AllowedVia Placement
Rx, Tx6Total Channel

SPI0 Flash 50MHz 2 to 5-Load Branch (Device Down) with G3 Flash Sharing Topology Notes
NoteDetail
Reference planeContinuous ground only.
Max frequencyFlash 1 & Flash 2: 50 MHz. EC: 50 MHz. TPM: 33 MHz.
R124 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 5.08 mm from the branch on SPI0_CLK, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3.
R251 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 5.08 mm from the branch on SPI0_CLK, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3.
Length from processor to flash 1 or flash 2Length from processor to flash 1 or flash 2: = BO + M1 + M2 + M3 + M4
Flash device electrical characteristics recommendation for 50MHz support: Option 1[1] Driver strength spec: 50 Ω or stronger across worse case corners. [2] 0.4 ns ≤ rise/ fall time measured at 30% to 70% ≤ 1.45 ns based on 30 pF test load. [3] Output capacitance, Cout ≤ 16 pF (including RPMC die). [4] Input capacitance, Cin ≤ 12 pF (including RPMC die). [5] Data input setup time ≤ 3 ns. [6] Data input hold time ≤ 3 ns. [7] CLK to DATA output valid time, min: 1 ns, based on 30 pF test load. [8] CLK to DATA output valid time, max: 6.5 ns (50% to 50%), based on 30 pF test load.
Flash device electrical characteristics recommendation for 50MHz support: Option 2[1] Driver strength spec: 40 Ω or stronger across worse case corners. [2] 0.4 ns ≤ rise/ fall time measured at 30% to 70% ≤ 1.25 ns based on 30 pF test load. [3] Output capacitance, Cout ≤ 14 pF (including RPMC die). [4] Input capacitance, Cin ≤ 12 pF (including RPMC die). [5] Data input setup time ≤ 3 ns. [6] Data input hold time ≤ 3 ns. [7] CLK to DATA output valid time, min: 1 ns, based on 30 pF test load. [8] CLK to DATA output valid time, max: 9 ns (50% to 50%), based on 30 pF test load.
Stuffing resistorIf one of devices is unstuffed (rework), treat it as (n - 1)-Load topology thus place stuffing resistor as close as possible to the branch to avoid long stub length.
FET component criteriaRon < 4.5 Ω. Cin < 6 pF.
Length matching between CLK and DATA/ CS# signals12.7 mm
Trace spacing between DATA and DATA signals0.250 mm
Trace spacing between CLK and DATA/ other signals0.375 mm
Signal name/ listSPI0_CLK, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_IO2, SPI0_IO3, SPI0_CS[0:1]# (for flash), SPI0_CS2# (for TPM)

SPI0 Flash 50MHz 2 to 3-Load Branch (Device Down) with G3 Wired-OR Topology

SPI0 2-Load Branch (Device Down) with G3 Wired-OR Topology Diagram
SPI0 3-Load Branch (Device Down) with G3 Wired-OR of Flash and TPM Topology Diagram
SPI0 3-Load Branch (Device Down) with G3 Wired-OR of Flash Topology Diagram
SPI0 Flash 50MHz 2 to 3-Load Branch (Device Down) with G3 Wired-OR Topology Notes
NoteDetail
Reference planeContinuous ground only.
Max frequencyFlash 1 & Flash 2: 50 MHz. EC: 50 MHz. TPM: 33 MHz.
Flash ProgrammerRequire additional isolation circuitry to protect processor from back-feed voltage when connect to flash programmer.
EC and processor branch requirementDelta between BO + M1 + M2 and M7 + M8 shall not exceed 25.4 mm.
Flash branch requirement, M3 + M4SPI branches of segment M3 + M4 need length matching within 2.54mm.
R1[1] DATA: 18 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 15.24 mm from the branch on SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3. [2] CLK: 24 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 15.24 mm from the branch on SPI0_CLK.
R218 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 12.7 mm from the branch on SPI0_CLK, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3.
R351 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 12.7 mm from the branch on SPI0_CLK, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3.
Flash device electrical characteristics recommendation for 50MHz support: Option 1[1] Driver strength spec: 50 Ω or stronger across worse case corners. [2] 0.4 ns ≤ rise/ fall time measured at 30% to 70% ≤ 1.45 ns based on 30 pF test load. [3] Output capacitance, Cout ≤ 16 pF (including RPMC die). [4] Input capacitance, Cin ≤ 12 pF (including RPMC die). [5] Data input setup time ≤ 3 ns. [6] Data input hold time ≤ 3 ns. [7] CLK to DATA output valid time, min: 1 ns, based on 30 pF test load. [8] CLK to DATA output valid time, max: 6.5 ns (50% to 50%), based on 30 pF test load.
Flash device electrical characteristics recommendation for 50MHz support: Option 2[1] Driver strength spec: 40 Ω or stronger across worse case corners. [2] 0.4 ns ≤ rise/ fall time measured at 30% to 70% ≤ 1.25 ns based on 30 pF test load. [3] Output capacitance, Cout ≤ 14 pF (including RPMC die). [4] Input capacitance, Cin ≤ 12 pF (including RPMC die). [5] Data input setup time ≤ 3 ns. [6] Data input hold time ≤ 3 ns. [7] CLK to DATA output valid time, min: 1 ns, based on 30 pF test load. [8] CLK to DATA output valid time, max: 9 ns (50% to 50%), based on 30 pF test load.
Length matching between CLK and DATA/ CS# signals12.7 mm
Trace spacing between DATA and DATA signals0.250 mm
Trace spacing between CLK and DATA/ other signals0.375 mm
Signal name/ listSPI0_CLK, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_IO2, SPI0_IO3, SPI0_CS[0:1]# (for flash), SPI0_CS2# (for TPM).

SPI0 Flash 50MHz 4-Load Branch (Device Down) with G3 Wired-OR Topology

SPI0 4-Load Branch (Device Down) with G3 Wired-OR Topology Diagram
SPI0 Flash 50MHz 4-Load Branch (Device Down) with G3 Wired-OR Topology Notes
NoteDetail
Reference planeContinuous ground only.
Max frequencyFlash 1 & Flash 2: 50 MHz. TPM & EC: 33 MHz.
Flash ProgrammerRequire additional isolation circuitry to protect processor from back-feed voltage when connect to flash programmer.
EC and processor branch requirementDelta between BO + M1 + M2 and M7 + M8 shall not exceed 12.7 mm.
Flash branch requirement, M3 + M4SPI branches of segment M3 + M4 need length matching within 2.54mm.
R1[1] DATA: 13 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 10.16 mm from the branch on SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3. [2] CLK: 24 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 10.16 mm from the branch on SPI0_CLK.
R213 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 12.7 mm from the branch on SPI0_CLK, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3.
R368 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 12.7 mm from the branch on SPI0_CLK, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3.
Flash device electrical characteristics recommendation for 50MHz support: Option 1[1] Driver strength spec: 50 Ω or stronger across worse case corners. [2] 0.4 ns ≤ rise/ fall time measured at 30% to 70% ≤ 1.45 ns based on 30 pF test load. [3] Output capacitance, Cout ≤ 16 pF (including RPMC die). [4] Input capacitance, Cin ≤ 12 pF (including RPMC die). [5] Data input setup time ≤ 3 ns. [6] Data input hold time ≤ 3 ns. [7] CLK to DATA output valid time, min: 1 ns, based on 30 pF test load. [8] CLK to DATA output valid time, max: 6.5 ns (50% to 50%), based on 30 pF test load.
Flash device electrical characteristics recommendation for 50MHz support: Option 2[1] Driver strength spec: 40 Ω or stronger across worse case corners. [2] 0.4 ns ≤ rise/ fall time measured at 30% to 70% ≤ 1.25 ns based on 30 pF test load. [3] Output capacitance, Cout ≤ 14 pF (including RPMC die). [4] Input capacitance, Cin ≤ 12 pF (including RPMC die). [5] Data input setup time ≤ 3 ns. [6] Data input hold time ≤ 3 ns. [7] CLK to DATA output valid time, min: 1 ns, based on 30 pF test load. [8] CLK to DATA output valid time, max: 9 ns (50% to 50%), based on 30 pF test load.
Length matching between CLK and DATA/ CS# signals12.7 mm
Trace spacing between DATA and DATA signals0.250 mm
Trace spacing between CLK and DATA/ other signals0.375 mm
Signal name/ listSPI0_CLK, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_IO2, SPI0_IO3, SPI0_CS[0:1]# (for flash), SPI0_CS2# (for TPM).

SPI0 Flash 76.8MHz and 100MHz 1 to 3-Load Branch (Device Down) MAF Topology

SPI0 Flash 100MHz and 76.8MHz 1 Load (Device Down) MAF Topology Diagram
SPI0 Flash 100MHz and 76.8MHz 2 Load Branch (Device Down) MAF with Flash and TPM Topology Diagram
SPI0 Flash 100MHz and 76.8MHz 3 Load Branch (Device Down) MAF Topology Diagram
SPI0 Flash 76.8MHz and 100MHz 1 to 3-Load Branch (Device Down) MAF Topology Notes
NoteDetail
Reference planeContinuous ground only.
Max frequencyFlash 1: 100 MHz. TPM and Debug Tool: < 14.3 MHz.
Flash ProgrammerRequire additional isolation circuitry to protect processor from back-feed voltage when connect to flash programmer.
R1[1] 22 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 12.7 mm from flash device on SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3. [2] 10 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 12.7 mm from flash device on SPI0_CLK.
R2430 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 2.54 mm from the branch on SPI0_CLK, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3.
Length from processor to Flash 1Length from processor to flash 1: = BO + M1 + M2 + M3 + M4
Routing schemeInterleave 1 CS with every 2 DATA lanes is recommended. Recommend to route DATA and CLK on same layer.
Flash device electrical characteristics recommendation for 100MHz and 76.8MHz support[1] Driver strength spec: 50 Ω or stronger across worse case corners. [2] 0.4 ns ≤ rise/ fall time measured at 30% to 70% ≤ 2 ns based on 30 pF test load. [3] Output capacitance, Cout ≤ 16 pF (including RPMC die). [4] Input capacitance, Cin ≤ 12 pF (including RPMC die). [5] Data input setup time ≤ 1.75 ns. [6] Data input hold time ≤ 2 ns. [7] CLK to DATA output valid time, min: 1 ns, based on 30 pF test load. [8] CLK to DATA output valid time, max: 6 ns (50% to 50%), based on 30 pF test load.
Length matching between CLK and DATA/ CS# signals12.7 mm
Trace spacing between DATA and DATA signals0.250 mm
Trace spacing between CLK and DATA/ other signals0.375 mm
Signal name/ listSPI0_CLK, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_IO2, SPI0_IO3, SPI0_CS0# (for flash), SPI0_CS2# (for TPM)

SPI0 Flash 76.8MHz and 100MHz 2 to 4-Load Branch (Device Down) with G3 Flash Sharing Topology

SPI0 Flash 76.8MHz and 100MHz 2 to 4-Load Branch (Device Down) with G3 Flash Sharing Topology Notes
NoteDetail
Reference planeContinuous ground only.
Max frequencyFlash 1: 100 MHz. TPM and Debug Tool: < 14.3 MHz. EC: 50MHz.
R110 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 12.7 mm (100 MHz) & 15.24 mm (76.8 MHz) from flash device on SPI0_CLK. 16 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 12.7 mm (100 MHz) & 15.24 mm (76.8 MHz) from flash device on SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3.
R2430 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 2.54 mm from the branch on SPI0_CLK, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3.
Length from processor to Flash 1Length from processor to flash 1: = BO + M1 + M2 + M3 + M4
Routing schemeInterleave 1 CS with every 2 DATA lanes is recommended. Recommend to route DATA and CLK on same layer.
Flash device electrical characteristics recommendation for 100MHz support[1] Driver strength spec: 40 Ω or stronger across worse case corners. [2] 0.4 ns ≤ rise/ fall time measured at 30% to 70% ≤ 2 ns based on 30 pF test load. [3] Output capacitance, Cout ≤ 16 pF (including RPMC die). [4] Input capacitance, Cin ≤ 12 pF (including RPMC die). [5] Data input setup time ≤ 1.75 ns. [6] Data input hold time ≤ 2 ns. [7] CLK to DATA output valid time, min: 1 ns, based on 30 pF test load. [8] CLK to DATA output valid time, max: 6 ns (50% to 50%), based on 30 pF test load.
Flash device electrical characteristics recommendation for 76.8MHz support[1] Driver strength spec: 50 Ω or stronger across worse case corners. [2] 0.4 ns ≤ rise/ fall time measured at 30% to 70% ≤ 2 ns based on 30 pF test load. [3] Output capacitance, Cout ≤ 16 pF (including RPMC die). [4] Input capacitance, Cin ≤ 12 pF (including RPMC die). [5] Data input setup time ≤ 1.75 ns. [6] Data input hold time ≤ 2 ns. [7] CLK to DATA output valid time, min: 1 ns, based on 30 pF test load. [8] CLK to DATA output valid time, max: 6 ns (50% to 50%), based on 30 pF test load.
FET component criteriaRon < 4.5 Ω. Cin < 6 pF.
Length matching between CLK and DATA/ CS# signals12.7 mm
Trace spacing between DATA and DATA signals0.250 mm
Trace spacing between CLK and DATA/ other signals0.375 mm

NoteDetail
Reference planeContinuous ground only.
Max frequencyFlash 1: 100 MHz. TPM and Debug Tool: < 14.3 MHz. EC: 50MHz.
R1[1] 9.1 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 12.7 mm from flash device on SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3. [2] 0 Ω placeholder. To be placed within 12.7 mm from flash device on SPI0_CLK.
R2430 Ω ± 5%. To be placed within 2.54 mm from the branch on SPI0_CLK, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3.
R3Placeholder for PPV implementation. Unstuff by default.
R40 Ω. To be placed within 2.54 mm from the FET (for debug) on SPI0_CLK, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3.
R50 Ω. To be placed within 2.54 mm from the branch on SPI0_CLK, SPI0_MISO, SPI0_MOSI, SPI0_IO2 and SPI0_IO3.
Length from processor to Flash 1Length from processor to flash 1: = BO + M1 + M2 + M3 + M4
Minimum length, totalBO + M1 + M2 + M3 + M4 = 40.64mm

[2] 0.4 ns ≤ rise/ fall time measured at 30% to 70% ≤ 1.7 ns based on 30 pF test load. [3] Output capacitance, Cout ≤ 16 pF (including RPMC die). [4] Input capacitance, Cin ≤ 12 pF (including RPMC die). [5] Data input setup time ≤ 1.75 ns. [6] Data input hold time ≤ 2 ns. [7] CLK to DATA output valid time, min: 1 ns, based on 30 pF test load. [8] CLK to DATA output valid time, max: 6 ns (50% to 50%), based on 30 pF test load.
FET component criteriaRon < 4.5 Ω. Cin < 6 pF.

Trace spacing between DATA and DATA signals0.250 mm
Trace spacing between CLK and DATA/ other signals0.375 mm

NoteDetail
R10 Ω placeholder is recommended, but not mandatory. If failing device overshoot/ undershoot, a 33 Ω resistor can be stuffed. If possible work with device vendor to determine necessity of R1. Must be placed within 50.8 mm from processor.

SVID

SVID 1-Load (Device Down) Topology

SVID 1-Load (Device Down) Topology Diagram
SVID 1-Load (Device Down) Topology Notes
NoteDetail
VIDSOUT platform resistorsRpu1 = 160 Ω, Rpu2 = 160 Ω, R1 = 10 Ω, R2 = 15 Ω.
VIDSCK platform resistorsRpu1 = Empty, Rpu2 = 82 Ω, R1 = 0 Ω / Short pad, R2 = 15 Ω.
VIDSALERT# platform resistorsRpu1 = 100 Ω, Rpu2 = Empty, R1 = 0 Ω / Short pad, R2 = 0 Ω / Short pad.
Platform resistor tolerance± 5%
Resistor Placement Recommendation (Rpu1, R1, Rpu2, R2)The Rpu1 & R1 resistor should be place close to processor and Rpu2 & R2 resistor should be place close to IMVP.
Clarification about Rpu1/ Rpu2/ R1/ R2 = Empty/ 0 Ω/ Short Pad[1] Rpu1 or Rpu2 = Empty; The specific side of the trace related to Rpu1 = Empty or Rpu2 = Empty does not need a pull-up resistor to the 1.05V power rail. [2] R1 or R2 = 0 Ω/ Short Pad; The signal does not need a series resistor for the specific part on the trace which is being represented by R1 or R2. Be aware, the trace still needs to remain connected end to end. * It is strongly recommended to refer for the implementation on RVP.
Gen5 VRTT tool validation Stuff VIDSOUT R1 with 0 Ω if VIDSOUT signal swing fails VIL with Gen5 VRTT tool.
Maximum trace DC resistance 7 Ω
Signal PTH/ via transitionSuggest having a GND stitching vias for each signal transition. The GND stitching vias to the signal vias need to be within 5.08 mm from one another.
Reference planeContinuous ground only.
Essential guidelines for routing near switching voltage regulator circuitIt is strongly recommended to meet routing near switching voltage regulator guidelines for SVID signals. Refer to "Switching VR Circuit Guideline" chapter in PDG for the details. (Technical White Paper Doc#:  726825)
Route orderingWhen routing at minimum spacing route ALERT between DATA and CLK.
Length matching between VIDSOUT and VIDSCK± 2.54 mm
Signal name/ listVIDSOUT, VIDSCK, VIDALERT#.

Signal GroupMax Number of Vias AllowedVia Placement

THC-SPI

THC-SPI 1-Load (for Touch Panel) Topology

THC-SPI 1-Load (for Touch Panel) Topology Diagram
THC-SPI 1-Load (for Touch Panel) Topology Notes
NoteDetail
Reference plane[1] Continuous GND is recommended. [2] If continuous GND cannot be implemented, a combination of GND on one side and continuous power plane on the other side with the condition that the GND plane be the closer reference (dual-reference) can be implemented. The continuous power plane requires low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt). [3] If non-continuous power referencing is required on microstrip/ surface layer, signal can reference over power planes with a low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt).
Max frequency42.67MHz (Please contact Intel for higher frequency enabling)
R118 Ω ± 5% To be placed 12.7 mm from the connector on THC[0:1]_SPI_CLK and THC[0:1]_SPI_IO[0:3].
M_cableRecommended to use shielded cable.
M_cable electrical characteristics-0.075 dB/inch < Insertion loss < -0.052 dB/inch -32.8 dB < Return loss < -46.2 dB -45.4 dB < Crosstalk < -47.2 dB 42 Ω < Impedance < 62 Ω
Minimum length, total78.74 mm
Length matching between CLK and DATA/ CS# signals12.7 mm
Trace spacing between DATA and DATA signals0.125 mm
Trace spacing between CLK and DATA/ other signals0.375 mm
Devices Electrical AssumptionsPlease refer to "SPI Interface and Electrical Assumptions for the Touch Device" chapter in Intel Touch Host Controller Integration Guide for further detials. (Touch Integration Guide Doc#: 778513)
Processor buffer driver strength40 Ω.
Signal name/ listTHC0_SPI_CLK, THC0_SPI_IO[0:3], THC0_SPI_CS#, THC0_RST#, THC0_INT#, THC1_SPI_CLK, THC1_SPI_IO[0:3], THC1_SPI_CS#, THC1_RST#, THC1_INT#.

Signal GroupMax Number of Vias AllowedVia Placement

The continuous power plane requires low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt). R113 Ω. Recommended to be placed 12.7 mm from processor, but can be extended to 50.8 mm maximum if required.

UFS Reference Clock

UFS Reference Clock 1-Load (Device Down) Topology

UFS Reference Clock Device Down Topology Diagram
UFS Reference Clock 1-Load (Device Down) Topology Notes
NoteDetail
Resistor values (for step down from 1.8 V to 1.2 V) R1 = 47 Ω R2 = 150 Ω To be placed within 25.4 mm to UFS device
Capacitor, CPlaceholder shunt capacitor (unstuff by default). To be placed near R1 Refer to EMC chapter in the PDG for more details
Platform resistor tolerance± 5%
Reference plane[1] Continuous GND is recommended. [2] If continuous GND cannot be implemented, a combination of GND on one side and continuous power plane on the other side with the condition that the GND plane be the closer reference (dual-reference) can be implemented. The continuous power plane requires low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt). [3] If non-continuous power referencing is required on microstrip/ surface layer, signal can reference over power planes with a low peak-to-peak noise and low current switching speed (di/dt).
Microstrip routing limitationDue to potential RF interference concerns, it is recommended not to route UFS REFCLK signal on microstrip layer for the main route segment

RTC

RTC (Real Time Clock) Topology

32.768 kHz RTC Crystal Topology Diagram
RTC (Real Time Clock) Topology Notes
NoteDetail
Length matching between RTC_X1 and RTC_X2Total length mismatch: 1.27 mm
GND shieldingGND shielding to adjacent signals (especially high speed IO) is recommended.
Reference planeContinuous GND only; do not reference to power planes. If routed as stripline or dual stripline, both top and bottom reference/ adjacent planes MUST be solid continuous ground.
External capacitor valuesExternal capacitors C1 and C2 must be matched (C1 = C2). Capacitor values should be tuned accordingly with respect to load capacitance for RTC crystal If the crystal load capacitance reduces (per component datasheet information), then C1/C2 should be reduced accordingly as well. For example, if the Cload is close to 10pF, then a more optimized C1/C2 value would be closer to 10pF (instead of 14pF) Due to vendor variation in crystal characteristic, layout variation and PCB trace, calculation is recommended to determine the C1/C2 value.
Main route (MR)Main route (MR) is recommended to be limited to SL/ DSL to limit coupling and impact from EMI/ RFI sources.
Max Number of vias
Signal GroupMax Number of Vias AllowedVia PlacementNotes
Tx2Total Channelrecommended to minimize number of vias

Segment Lengths

RTC (Real Time Clock) Topology Segment Lengths Routing Guidelines
SegmentTline TypeMax Length Segment (mm)
BOMS, DSL, SL12.7
MRDSL, SL

Max Length Total (mm): 20.3

Max Length Total Note: Max length of 20.3 mm is based on 0402 resistor and capacitor sizes assumption. Max length can be 25.4 mm if component sizes are reduced from 0402 to 0201.

XTAL

Crystal Oscillator Topology

Crystal Oscillator (38.4 MHz) Topology Diagram
Crystal Oscillator Topology Notes
NoteDetail
Length matching between XTAL_IN and XTAL_OUTTotal length mismatch: 1.27 mm.
GND shieldingGND shielding to adjacent signals (especially high speed IO) is recommended.
Main route (MR)Main route (MR) is recommended to be limited to SL/ DSL to limit coupling and impact from EMI/ RFI sources.
Reference planeContinuous GND only; do not reference to power planes. If routed as stripline or dual stripline, both top and bottom reference/ adjacent planes MUST be solid continuous ground. Avoid routing directly parallel (under/ over/shadow) to high current power planes. If unavoidable route signal orthogonal to power plane.
External capacitor valueExternal capacitors C1 and C2 must be matched (C1 = C2).Capacitor values should be tuned accordingly with respect to load capacitance for crystal. If the crystal load capacitance reduces (per component datasheet information), then C1/C2 should be reduced accordingly as well. Due to vendor variation in crystal characteristic, layout variation and PCB trace, calculation is recommended to determine the C1/C2 value.
Max Number of vias
Signal GroupMax Number of Vias AllowedVia PlacementNotes
Tx2Total Channelrecommended to minimize number of vias

FORCEPR#

FORCEPR# Topology

FORCEPR# Topology Diagram
FORCEPR# Topology Notes
NoteDetail
R-1, R-2, R-n75 Ω ≤ R-n + Dev-n drive strength ≤ 200 Ω. [1] Drive strength of each device should be controlled within 75 Ω to 200 Ω, use an additional resistor if the device drive strength is too strong. [2] Optionally, if the device drive strength is ≥ 75 Ω (weak), R-n is not needed. [3] Recommended to be placed < 127 mm from respective device.
Rpu2.2 kΩ ± 20%. Total length can be extended up to 1524 mm. Refer to "FORCEPR# Topology Routing Length vs Rpu Guideline Table" for details.

R0 Ω

EIO Flexi-PDG for I2C and SMLink

Description: EIO Flexi-PDG for I2C and SMLink

Processor Sideband

LPDDR5/x

CAMM2 x128 Type-3

Pcb Type & Thickness: Type-3, 0.8mm

LPCAMM2 x128 Type-3 PCB DQ, DQS, CA, CS, CLK Topology Diagram
LPCAMM2 x128 Type-3 Reset and RCOMP Topology Diagram
LPCAMM2 x128 Type-3 CAMM Placement and Block Diagram
CAMM2 x128 Type-3 Notes
NoteDetail
LPCAMM2 connectorIntel recommends to follow the latest version LPCAMM2 connector CAD symbol from JEDEC Spec.
PCB stackupType-3 stackup with minimum of 8 layers.
Layer assignment rulesOuter Row DQ signals on layer3 and Inner Row DQ signals on Layer 7. CAC Signals in layer 5.
Reference planeContinuous ground only.
Number of vias allowedDQ/ RDQS/WCK CA/ CS/ CLK: Max 2 vias,
GND stitchingFor VSS stitching using microvia, target a minimum S:G ratio of 1:1 at signal layer transition. For VSS stitching using PTH, target a minimum S:G ratio of 2:1 at signal layer transition. VSS via stitching pattern to be copied exactly from RVP/ clip files.
Max MS BO/ BI lengthRefer to RFI/ EMC guidelines for the maximum microstrip BO/ BI length requirement.
Serpentine routingUse 3x of dielectric height for serpentine routing spacing.
Bit/ Byte swapping ruleBit swapping is allowed within each Byte for all memory technologies. Byte swapping is allowed within a 16-bit channel. LPDDR5: x16 sub-channels can be swizzled within their x64 MC. When swapping channel DQ, the CA/CS signals must be swapped as well.
Unused signalsLeave unused DDR signals (PARITY, extra CA) floating (no connect). ALERT is also unused and can be left floating (no connect) at processor side.
Rtt/ Ctt for RESETKeep R1 empty; R2 = 0 Ohm; C1 = 0.1 uF (no stuff).
RCOMP value100 Ohm
Max number of vias
Signal GroupMax Number of Vias Allowed
CA, CLK, CS, DQ, RDQS, WCK2

Max Length Total Note: Max length is package + motherboard.

MD x32 Type-3

Pcb Type & Thickness: Type-3, 0.9mm

LPDDR5/x x32 Type-3 PCB DQ, DQS, CA, CS, CLK Topology Diagram
LPDDR5/x x32 Type-3 Reset and RCOMP Topology Diagram
LPDDR5_x x32 Type-3 Memory Down Placement and Block Diagram
MD x32 Type-3 Notes
NoteDetail
PCB stackupType-3 stackup with minimum of 10 layers.
Reference planeContinuous ground only.
GND stitchingFor VSS stitching using microvia, target a minimum S:G ratio of 1:1 at signal layer transition. For VSS stitching using PTH, target a minimum S:G ratio of 2:1 at signal layer transition. VSS via stitching pattern to be copied exactly from RVP/ clip files.
Max MS BO/ BI lengthRefer to RFI/ EMC guidelines for the maximum microstrip BO/ BI length requirement.
Serpentine routingUse 3x of dielectric height for serpentine routing spacing.
Bit/ Byte swapping ruleBit swapping is allowed within each Byte for all memory technologies. Byte swapping is allowed within a 16-bit channel. LPDDR5: x16 sub-channels can be swizzled within their x64 MC. When swapping channel DQ, the CA/CS signals must be swapped as well.
Unused signalsLeave unused DDR signals (PARITY, extra CA) floating (no connect). ALERT is also unused and can be left floating (no connect) at processor side.
Rtt/ Ctt for RESETKeep R1 empty; R2 = 0 Ohm; C1 = 0.1 uF (no stuff).
RCOMP value100 Ohm
DDR to Non-DDR trace spacingMinimum 500 um.
Max number of vias
Signal GroupMax Number of Vias Allowed
CA, CLK, CS, DQ, RDQS, WCK2
RCOMP1

Signal Group: CA, CLK, CS, DQ, RDQS, WCK

Pin group/Location: Outer

Channels: CH-0, CH-2, CH-4, CH-6

Signal MRTS
Segment NameCategoryStartEnd
SoCDevice01
BO1Trace12
Via1Via23
BO2Trace34
MTrace45
BI1Trace56
Via2Via67
BI2Trace78

Length Matching

MD x32 Type-3 Length Matching
Signal GroupPlus/MinusReference GroupWithin/GroupUp to memory/connectorLength/DelayMin/Max/RangeMinMax
DQ-WCKByte (x8)Same DRAMLength (mm)Range-1214
DQ-RDQSByte (x8)Same DRAMLength (mm)Range-33
WCK-CLKChannel (x16)Same DRAMLength (mm)Range-510
DQ-DQByte (x8)Same DRAMLength (mm)Max4
CLK-CAChannel (x16)Same DRAMLength (mm)Range-55
CA-CAChannel (x16)Same DRAMLength (mm)Max7.5
CLK-CSChannel (x16)Same DRAMLength (mm)Range-12.512.5
CS-CSChannel (x16)Same DRAMLength (mm)Max10
RDQS_P-RDQS_NPair (P-N)Same DRAMLength (mm)Max0.1
WCK_P-WCK_NPair (P-N)Same DRAMLength (mm)Max0.1
CLK_P-CLK_NPair (P-N)Same DRAMLength (mm)Max0.1
CLK-CLKAll ChannelsWithin DRAMLength (mm)Max25

MD x32 Type-4

Pcb Type & Thickness: Type-4 2-x-2+, 0.8mm

LPDDR5/x x32 Type4 DQ, RDQS, WCK, CA, CS, CLK Topology Diagram
LPDDR5/x x32 Type-4 Reset and RCOMP Topology Diagram
LPDDR5_x x32 Type-4 Memory Down Placement and Block Diagram
MD x32 Type-4 Notes
NoteDetail
PCB stackupType-4 (2-x-2+) stackup with minimum of 10 layers.
Layer assignment rulesOuter row DQ on layer 2, Inner row DQ on layer 4, CAC can be on layer 6/8. Please follow RVP / Clip files for the layer assignment details.
Reference planeContinuous ground only.
Number of vias allowedDQ/ RDQS/ WCK: max 2 vias ; Only micro-vias allowed. CA/ CS/ CLK: max 2 vias; Both micro-vias & PTH allowed.
GND stitchingFor VSS stitching using microvia, target a minimum S:G ratio of 1:1 at signal layer transition. For VSS stitching using PTH, target a minimum S:G ratio of 2:1 at signal layer transition. VSS via stitching pattern to be copied exactly from RVP / Clip files.
Serpentine routingUse 3x of dielectric height for serpentine routing spacing. Do not apply serpentine routing in the break-out region.
Bit/ Byte swapping ruleBit swapping is allowed within each Byte for all memory technologies. Byte swapping is allowed within a 16-bit channel. LPDDR5: x16 sub-channels can be swizzled within their x64 MC. When swapping channel DQ, the CA/CS signals must be swapped as well.
Unused signalsLeave unused DDR signals (PARITY, extra CA) floating (no connect). ALERT is also unused and can be left floating (no connect) at processor side.
Rtt/ Ctt for RESETKeep R1 empty; R2 = 0 Ohm; C1 = 0.1 uF (no stuff).
RCOMP value100 Ohm
DDR to Non-DDR trace spacingMinimum 500 um.

DDR5

Description: DDR5 SODIMM

SODIMM 1DPC Type-3

Pcb Type & Thickness: Type-3, 0.8mm

DDR5 SODIMM Type-3 8L Signals Topologies
DDR5 SODIMM Side-by-Side Placement Block Diagram
DDR5 SODIMM Back-to-Back Placement Block Diagram
DDR5 SODIMM 1DPC Top-Pin Bottom-Pin Definition and Compensation
SODIMM 1DPC Type-3 Notes
NoteDetail
PCB stackupType-3 stackup with minimum of 8 layer.
Layer assignment rulesFollow the reference design (RVP).
Reference planeContinuous ground only.
Number of vias allowedMax 2 transition vias.
Ground stitchingFor VSS stitching using microvia, target a minimum S:G ratio of 1:1 at signal layer transition. For VSS stitching using PTH, target a minimum S:G ratio of 2:1 at signal layer transition. VSS via stitching pattern to be copied exactly from RVP / clip files.
Max MS BO/ BI lengthRefer to RFI/ EMC guidelines for the max microstrip BO/ BI length requirement.
Serpentine routingUse 3x of dielectric height for serpentine routing spacing.
Bit/ Byte swapping ruleBit swapping is allowed within each Byte for all memory technologies. DDR5: Byte Swapping is allowed within each x32 channel.
Diff pair length matchingMatch diff pair P-N within 0.2 mm at each layer.
MS BO and BI segment, PTH patternKeep DDR MS BO and BI as close as possible to reference board.
DDR to Non-DDR trace spacingMinimum 500 um.
Unused signalsDDR signals on processor which are not applicable for DDR5 can be left unconnected
Rtt/ Ctt for RESETKeep R1 empty; R2 = 0 Ohm; C1 = 0.1 uF (no stuff).
RCOMP value100 Ohm

EMC General Considerations

Ground Ring

PCB ground (GND) rings on all layers with GND PTH vias are recommended along the edge of the board. Multiple mounting holes should be used connecting the PCB GND to chassis ground. It can significantly reduce the PCB edge coupled noise.

Guidelines for PCB GND Ring and GND Stitching Vias

Multiple GND stitching vias are required on all mechanical mounting pads including for internal device modules (e.g. SSD, WiFi module) and I/O connectors (e.g. USB, DP) throughout the platform.

Ground Ring with Ground Vias

Connector Decoupling

Place a decoupling capacitor (0.1 uF, 0402 or smaller) on the power pins of all internal and external connectors to reduce power noise. These connectors include HDMI, DP, eDP, USB, Type C, FPC connectors, M.2, PCIe edge connector, etc.

Decoupling Capacitors Placement on Connector Power Pins

Crossing Splits in Reference Plane

Crossing a split in the reference plane increases emissions from signal traces. Avoid crossing plane splits by moving the traces or reshape the reference plane.

Avoid Signal Traces Routings Across Split Planes

Reference Discontinuity

Changing reference plane from GND to power plane, or from power plane A to power plane B, may significantly increase noise emission. It is recommended to have stitching capacitors (0.1 uF, 0402 or smaller) to bridge the two reference planes and provide current return path and the stitching capacitor must be placed as close as possible to the signal trace.

Reduce Signal Referencing Discontinuities Impact

Crystal RF Immunity

The crystal oscillator that provides the input clock to the processor has been identified to be very sensitive to RF power from nearby radios. Radiated power from internal WWAN and WLAN antennas as well as from external WWAN/ WLAN devices placed near the platform can couple to the crystal and corrupt the clock signal causing issues such as screen flickering and system hang. Similarly, the crystal used with the Thunderbolt retimer is very sensitive to RF power, and noise from nearby antennas can result in connection loss with the device plugged into the Thunderbolt port. Refer to retimer collaterals in the EMC/RF Reference Documents section for XTAL specifications. The following RF Immunity Guidelines apply to both the 38.4 MHz crystal, RTC (real-time clock) crystal as well as the Thunderbolt retimer crystal.

  • Follow crystal routing guidelines very carefully. (Refer to XTAL section under High Speed I/Os chapter).

  • Implement a ground ring surrounding crystal and related components. Refer to the figure below. Do not connect external load caps to GND ring, but rather directly to GND plane on adjacent layer.

  • Use a shielded crystal component.

  • Ensure that clock and high-speed I/O traces are not routed in proximity to the crystal components and traces (XTAL_IN/OUT).

  • Place crystal far away from antennas and potential RF power coupling paths such as unshielded/ungrounded cables. The exact distance needed depends on the platform design. Platforms without board shield may have higher risk.

  • Chassis shielding and design plays a critical role in RF immunity. Refer to the EMC Mechanical Considerations section and collateral #602554.

The following RF guidelines apply to RTC (real-time) crystal:

  • Reserve a placeholder for the RF cap on the power plane for RTC. The capacitance of the stuffed RF cap can be tuned with respect to the potential unintended RF power. The footprint should be as close as possible to processor side.

RF Capacitor Placement Recommendation for RTC Crystal

Crystal Ground Ring Requirements

Adding a ground ring surrounding the crystal component, related components and routing can help reduce RF immunity risk.

Guidelines for Crystal Ground Ring Implementation and Components for RF

Memory RFI Mitigation

Memory interface and DRAM devices generate narrowband and broadband RFI noise. The noise may interfere with radio bands. The following guidelines help to reduce the RFI risk due to memory.

Memory RFI Mitigation Consideration

Design AreaRecommendations
Memory signals on Type-4 boardFull stripline routing required
Memory signals main routing on Type-3 boards Main routing full stripline required
Memory signals breakout routing on Type-3 boards DQ microstrip breakout signal = 6.5 mm CLK, WCK, DQS, CA microstrip breakout signal = 9 mm
Memory device (SODIMM, solder down memory, LPCAMM2) shielding Shield requirement depends on antenna placement and system design. Refer to the PDG chapter “On-Board Shielding”.
Embed memory power plane in inner layers of the board Follow “Power Integrity Recommendations” for memory power plane closely to embed these power planes. If embedding memory power plane is not possible, recommend either to shield exposed power plane or to add placeholders for RF capacitors.
DDR Radio Frequency Interference Mitigation (RFIM) Feature Recommended. Refer to RFIM white paper (Document # 640438)
Antenna barricade technology Recommended. Refer to “Antenna Barricade technology” section under “EMC Mechanical Considerations” PDG chapter or contact Intel for more information.

Memory Signals Design Guidelines

For Type-4 board, it is recommended that memory signals (DQ/ CLK/ DQS/ WCK/ CA) are fully routed in inner layers. For Type-3 board, it is recommended that main route of memory signals is routed as stripline; with minimum microstrip breakout and break-in length allowed, as shown in table below. An isolation ground guard ring is recommended on the surface layer between memory power plane and memory breakout signal routing.

Signal TypesTotal Microstrip Breakout Length (mm)
DQ<= 6.5
CLK, WCK, DQS, CA<= 9

* Break-in microstrip length should be ≤ 1.5 mm based on system dependency.

RFI Suppression Guidelines on Memory Signal and Power Plane Exposure

Memory Power Plane Routing Guidelines

It is strongly recommended to embed memory power planes in inner PCB layers with reference to solid ground on adjacent layers. Prioritizing embedding VDDQ over VDD2. For more details, refer to “Power Integrity Recommendations” to embed these power planes. Minimize exposure of memory power plane size on top and bottom layer of the board and keeping minimum routing for BGA and capacitors only.

If embedding memory power plane is not possible, please consider either one of the following recommendations:

  • Option 1: Consider covering exposed memory power planes with shield or absorber.

  • Option 2: Consider adding placeholders for platform RF capacitors to mitigate power plane noise. Refer to the figures and guidelines below.

Exposed Memory Power Plane RF Decoupling Capacitors

RF decoupling capacitors placement in processor area:

  • 12pF (0402) or 15pF (0201)

  • < 4 mm proximity from BGA of processor memory power plane

  • 2 to 3 capacitors are recommended

  • Reserve as placeholder (capacitors unstuffed)

RF decoupling capacitors placement in memory module area:

  • 12pF (0402) or 15pF (0201)

  • < 4 mm proximity from pins of memory devices

  • At least 2 capacitors per memory module

  • Reserve as placeholder (capacitors unstuffed)

2.4 GHz band effective RF capacitor values are to be found by RF interference measurements as their effectiveness depends on RF capacitor size, locations, number, and pad and via parasitic. Begin with RF capacitor values tested on Intel reference board and refine them further as needed.

The figures below show an example of RF decoupling capacitor placement on VDD2 LPDDR5x memory down in Type4 PCB:

RF Decoupling Capacitor Placement on VDD2 LPDDR5x Memory Down in Type 4 PCB

Memory Power Plane Routing Guidelines (Internal)

  • RF capacitor stuffing option: Stuffed for internal validation

Memory Devices

Memory devices (ex. DRAM, SODIMM, LPCAMM2) can radiate broadband and narrowband RFI noise and may cause radio frequency interference. A combination of EMI shield and antenna placement is one of the solutions to mitigate noise from memory devices.

SODIMM memory devices can cause higher RFI noise than the soldered down DRAM devices and it is recommended to use an EMI shield for the SODIMM memory devices and/or use the DDR RFI Mitigation (RFIM) feature.

Refer to the sections “On-Board Shielding” and “Intel DDR RFI Mitigation (RFIM) Software Feature” for more information.

LPCAMM2 PCB Design Guidelines

  1. Avoid exposed power planes

    • Avoid exposed memory power plane on top and bottom side of motherboard. Distribute GND stitching vias across the GND plane.

    • Avoid Exposed Memory Power Plane on Top and Bottom Side of Motherboard

  2. LPCAMM2 back plate grounding and module retention screws

    • For improved RFI performance, it is recommended to ensure a ground connection between the LPCAMM2 module and the PCB.

    • Expose ground pads with multiple ground stitching vias around mechanical mounting/screw holes on the bottom side of the motherboard PCB (to allow ground contact of the back plate).

    • A back plate with a custom nut (or EMI washer, alternatively) is recommended to ensure ground connection between back plate and PCB bottom layer ground.

    • The recommended back plate and threaded insert/custom nut dimensions are the following figure (in mm).

    • Conductive screws without any coating/paint are recommended to secure the module to the motherboard. The screw's dimensions guidelines (in mm) are based on a recommended LPCAMM2 module-level shield.

    • Provide solder mask opening for GND (VSS) around mounting holes
    • Back plate with threaded insert or nut for ground contact to PCB
    • Recommended LPCAMM2 module screw dimensions

  3. LPCAMM2 Module-level Shield

    • A module-level EMI shield can be installed on the LPCAMM2 module as illustrated in the pictures below. The shield must make ground contact to the ground ring on the periphery of the module. A top plate/EMI shield with conductive foam gaskets can be used to achieve the ground contact of the shield with the module PCB. The figures below show the recommended dimensions for the shield and conductive gaskets.

    • Optional on-module shield for LPCAMM2
    • Recommended dimensions for LPCAMM2 on-module shield
    • Critical dimensions for conductive gasket for LPCAMM2 on-module shield

  4. RFI-friendly LPCAMM2 connector option

    • To mitigate noise radiation from the LPCAMM2 connector, an optional RFI-friendly connector has been developed with connector vendors. The connector design is comprised of a thin metal shield layer along the periphery of the connector. The shield layer may wrap around the entire connector or only along the south-edge of the connector near the differential pins. The shield layer should contact the module ground and PCB ground using compression contacts. An illustration of the connector is shown below. Customers should contact their LPCAMM2 connector vendor for part numbers and details.

    • RFI-friendly LPCAMM2 Connector

Intel DDR RFI Mitigation (RFIM) Software Feature

DDR RFIM is a frequency-shifting RFI-mitigation software feature.  The DDR RFIM feature is primarily aimed at resolving narrowband RFI from memory (DDR and LPDDR technologies and both soldered-down and modules) for the Wi-Fi in high frequency bands (5 to 7GHz). By changing the DDR data rate, using Intel dynamic voltage and frequency scaling (DVFS) technology, the narrowband memory noise at the clock harmonic frequency can be shifted out of a radio band of interest, thus mitigating RFI to the radio. The change of the DDR data rate is dynamic based on the radio channel in use.

Dynamic DDR data rate selection and control can be done at the request of the Intel integrated Wi-Fi firmware (CNVi) or at the request of Intel’s DTT DDR RFIM policy. In systems with CNVi installed, the feature is enabled by default. In systems with discrete Intel or 3rd party Wi-Fi, the DDR RFIM policy must be enabled in DTT. For both cases, the OEM has the option to customize the DDR RFI table (list of Wi-Fi channels affected by each DDR frequency of the system) based on the measured platform noise.

Intel also offers a semiautomatic tool to characterize the platform DDR noise and customize the DDR RFI table that is an input to RFIM. It is highly recommended to use the tool to characterize the noise from the different memory DVFS points. Please refer to white papers #640438 and #816192 for detailed information.

DLVR RFI Design Guidelines

The Digital Linear Voltage Regulator (DLVR) may induce RF noise on input power planes / rails that couple to radio antennas, resulting in RF interference within radio bands.

The following guidelines help to reduce the RFI risk due to DLVR.

Minimize DLVR Input Power Planes’ Exposure

It is recommended that the DLVR input power plane (VCCCORE) size be minimized on surface layers while considering PI requirements. Refer to power integrity requirement for resistance and VR sense feedback recommendations.

RF Decoupling Capacitors on DLVR Input Power Planes

High-frequency decoupling capacitors on the DLVR input power plane(s) can help in DLVR noise-reduction. Since there are system-level dependencies for the RFI, in certain scenarios (like a system with aggressive antenna placement to DLVR input power plane or WWAN radio), it is recommended to have placeholders for decoupling capacitors. The following table and figures show the recommended values and placement for the decoupling capacitors and an example of layout implementation.

RF Decoupling Capacitor Guideline for DLVR
Example of RF Cap Placement for DLVR power plane

NPU RFI Mitigation

Neural Processing Unit (NPU) operates in a wide range of frequencies and its maximum operation frequency is getting higher gen-over-gen. NPU maximum frequency may operate at Wi-Fi band and interfere with Wi-Fi channels depending on the workload. Intel may update this content based on internal validation. Please contact Intel representative for details.

NPU RFI Mitigation Considerations

The following recommendations apply to the system that supports NPU maximum frequency of Wi-Fi frequency band:

Design RecommendationDetails
Proper thermal groundingRefer to “EMC Mechanical Considerations” PDG chapter for example.
Reserve on-board shielding especially SOC area or core areaEnsure proper shielding ground contact for shielding effectiveness. Refer to “Shielding Ground Contact” PDG section under “On-Board Shielding” chapter for details.
Antenna Barricade TechnologyRefer to “Antenna Barricade Technology” PDG section under EMC Mechanical Considerations chapter for more details.
Implement NPU power plane (VCCSA) RF decoupling capacitor placeholderRefer to “RF Decoupling Capacitors on NPU Power Planes” PDG section for guidelines.
Minimize NPU power plane size (VCCSA) on top and bottom of the motherboard

RF Decoupling Capacitors on NPU Power Plane

It is recommended to have placeholders for high-frequency decoupling capacitors on the VCCSA (NPU power plane). These decoupling capacitors may help in reducing potential NPU noise in certain scenarios such as a system with aggressive antenna placement to NPU power plane. The following table and figure show the recommended values and placement for the decoupling capacitors:

RF Decoupling Capacitor Guideline for NPU Power Plane
Case #Location of Decoupling CapacitorNPU RF Capacitors for 2.4GHz BandComments$[internal]Cap Stuffing Option for Internal Validation
Case 1Directly underneath pair of NPU power via and GND vias (Directly from BGAs) on the plane0201 size: 6 x capacitors (Suggested value: between 22pF to 33pF)Preferred placement for RF decoupling capacitors. Capacitors are recommended to be placed directly underneath the pair of NPU power via - GND vias at bottom layer or at least within the processor’s shadow area. The value of the RF capacitor may need to be tuned with respect to the potential unintended RF power within Wi-Fi bands. Stuffed 
Case 2≤ 5mm from NPU power via BGA 0201 size: 6 x capacitors (Suggested value: between 22pF to 33pF) The value of the RF capacitor may need to be tuned with respect to the potential unintended RF power within Wi-Fi bands.Stuffed 
Case 3 (Not Recommended)> 5mm away from NPU power via BGA Not recommended RF capacitors are NOT effective for RFI reduction in this location of placement.Stuffed 

Graphic (GFX) Power Planes RFI Design Guidelines

Graphics (GFX) may induce RF noise on power planes or rails that couple to radio antennas, resulting in RF interference within radio bands.

The following guidelines help to reduce the RFI risk due to GFX power planes.

RF Decoupling Capacitors on GFX Power Planes

It is recommended to have placeholders for high-frequency decoupling capacitors on the VCCGT (GFX power plane). These decoupling capacitors may help in reducing potential GFX noise in certain scenarios such as a system with aggressive antenna placement to GFX power planes. The following table and figure show the recommended values and placement for the decoupling capacitors:

Capacitors are recommended to be placed directly underneath the pair of GFX power via - GND vias at bottom layer or at least within the processor’s shadow area. The value of the RF capacitor may need to be tuned with respect to the potential unintended RF power within Wi-Fi bands. Stuffed
