Case 3 (Not recommended)> 5mm away from GFX power via BGA Not recommended RF capacitors are NOT effective for RFI reduction in this location of placement.Stuffed 

HSIO RFI Mitigation

Exposed high speed I/O routing traces are considered as RFI source. The RFI level depends on interface signal characteristics such as data rate and distance between antenna and signal trace.

Minimize Exposed High Speed I/O Channel Routing

It is recommended that the routing of I/O interfaces in the table below be embedded in inner layers and covered by solid ground. Due to routing limitations, full stripline routing may not be possible at breakout region and the routing at the connector region. Please refer to the table below for maximum microstrip length.

InterfaceData RateMax Routing Length at Breakout Region (Microstrip)Max Routing Length at Connector Region (Microstrip)Cable ShieldingNote
eUSB2 480 Mbps < 38 mm < 25 mm Shielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ Coax
UFS reference clock 38.4MHz < 38 mm < 25 mm Shielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ Coax Add a placeholder shunt capacitor (0402 or 0201 size) near to UFS device. Refer to UFS Reference Clock PDG chapter for more information about capacitor placement.
UFS 4.0 Gear 5 20 Gbps (Rate A), 23.32 Gbps (Rate B) < 38 mm < 25 mm Shielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ Coax
CNVio3 (STEP)12 GbpsRefer to CNVio3 section under High Speed I/Os chapter)Refer to CNVio3 section under High Speed I/Os chapter)Not applicableKeep out distance of CNVio3' signals (microstrip) to Wi-Fi antenna > 15 mm. Refer to Intel document #610694 for the latest Intel Wi-Fi module RFI/EMC recommendations.
DMIC Clk< 38 mm< 25 mmShielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ Coax
eDP 1.58.1 Gbps< 38 mm< 25 mmShielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ Coax
HDMI 2.05.94 Gbps< 38 mm< 25 mmShielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ Coax
HDMI 2.112 Gbps< 38 mm< 25 mmShielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ Coax
PCIe416 Gbps< 38 mm< 25 mmShielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ CoaxRefer to PCIe Gen4 Add-in Card Clock Topology or PCIe Gen4 Device Down Clock Topology (under High Speed I/Os) for more EMC/ RF noise protection recommendations.
PCIe532 Gbps< 38 mm< 25 mmShielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ CoaxRefer to PCIe Gen5 Add-in Card Clock Topology or PCIe Gen5 Device Down Clock Topology (under High Speed I/Os) for more EMC/ RF noise protection recommendations.
PCIe Refclk100 MHz< 38 mm< 25 mmShielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ CoaxRefer to PCIe Gen4/Gen5 Add-in Card Clock Topology or PCIe Gen4/Gen5 Device Down Clock Topology (under High Speed I/Os) for more EMC/ RF noise protection recommendations.
SPI Clk< 38 mm< 25 mmShielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ Coax
TBT580 Gbps< 38 mm< 25 mmShielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ Coax
USB3.2 Gen1Type A5 Gbps< 38 mm< 25 mmShielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ Coax
USB3.2 Gen2Type A10 Gbps< 38 mm< 25 mmShielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ Coax

For mechanical information, please refer to EMC Mechanical Considerations section.

eDP RFI Mitigation

RF Interference from Embedded Display Port (eDP) Interface and TCON

In mobile designs, RF interference from eDP interface has become more problematic due to the increase of thinner and lighter devices, which limit options for effective cable shielding and antenna isolation. While the data rates increase, the high-frequency data and clocks generate RF noise that falls into Wi-Fi radio bands. Besides RF noise from eDP, timing controller (TCON), used to convert the eDP signal and drive the individual pixels of the display, could be another source of interference.

Narrowband Spur Noise from eDP Data and TCON Clock

To prevent interference with radio bands, select the eDP data rates that ensure the fundamental frequencies and harmonics of the eDP signals do not fall into Wi-Fi radio bands. The eDP data rates 2.43 Gbps and 6.75 Gbps should be avoided to mitigate the RF noise impact on Wi-Fi radios. Other mitigation solutions such as using high-quality shielding cable for eDP and TCON connection/board or enabling spread spectrum clocking may provide effective but limited noise reduction as an alternative solution.

Mitigate RF interference by preventing using data rate falling into Wi-Fi radios
TCON clock noise falling into Wi-Fi bands

eUSB2V2 (Internal Validation)

It is recommended that eUSB2V2 routing be embedded in inner layers and covered by solid ground. Due to routing limitations, full stripline routing may not be possible at breakout region and the routing at the connector region. Please refer to the table below for maximum microstrip length.

InterfaceMax Routing Length at Breakout Region (Microstrip)Max Routing Length at Connector Region (Microstrip)Cable Shielding
eUSB2V2< 38 mm< 25 mmShielded FPC/ Shielded FFC/ Coax

EMC Component Selection

Common Mode Choke Selection

The common mode choke (CMC) selection is shown below.

Alternatively, PCB CMC can be also considered for eDP 1.4, eDP 1.5, Type-C USB+DP (10 Gbps), USB3.2 Gen 1 and USB3.2 Gen2 signal. Refer to #546122 for Intel PCB Common Mode Choke License Technology Technical White Paper.

Interface Data Rate CMC Placement CMC Cutoff Frequency (3dB Bandwidth) CMC Insertion Loss CM Rejection (10-dB Band) $[internal] Reference Part 
eDP 1.5 8.1 Gb/s < 25 mm routing length from connector > 10 GHz < 1.2 dB @ 5 GHz 1.8 - 3.8 GHz NFG0QHB372HS2 
HDMI 2.0   ≤ 6 Gb/s < 25 mm routing length from connector > 6 GHz < 0.35 dB @ 1.5 GHz, ​< 0.5 dB @ 3.0 GHz 0.3 - 3.8 GHz NFG0QHB372HS2
HDMI 2.1 12 Gb/s < 25 mm routing length from connector > 10 GHz < 1.0 dB @ 6 GHz 0.3 - 3.8 GHz NFG0QHB372HS2 
USB3.2 Gen 1/2 Type A≤ 10 Gb/s < 25 mm routing length from connector > 7.5 GHz < 1.5 dB @ 2.5 GHz, < 1.2 dB @ 5 GHz 1.8 - 3.8 GHz NFG0QHB372HS2 
eUSB2.0* 480 Mb/s < 25 mm routing length from connector < 0.2 dB @ 240 MHz 0.5 - 2.0 GHz DLW21SN900SQ2

* Common mode chokes with a target common mode impedance of 80 to 90 Ohm at 100 MHz generally provide adequate noise attenuation for USB2.0 and eUSB2.0.

Higher impedance CMC generally have a greater damaging effect on signal quality. Signal quality must be checked for low-speed, full-speed and high-speed USB operations in case if high impedance component is used.

CMC Placement Guideline for USB3 Interface

Port Usage ScenarioCMC Guideline
USB3 onlyPlace Tx CMCs; Rx CMCs are optional
USB3 & DPPlace both Tx and Rx CMCs due to emission from DP
USB3 & TBTDo not place either Tx or Rx CMCs

ESD Diode Selection

ESD diode selection recommendations below only apply to interfaces with:

  • Hotplug input/output port application (external ports that exposed to end user)

  • Direct connection between SOC and connector (Eg, without redriver / retimer in between)

For interfaces that require retimer:

  • Intel retimer: Please refer to Thunderbolt retimer or controller documentation for more details, document number can be found in PDG chapter “EMC/RF Reference Documents”.

  • Third party retimer: Customer may contact vendor for necessary ESD protection.

For further ESD design optimization, customers may refer to Chapter “System Efficient ESD Design (SEED)” for more details.

Interface Data Rate ESD Diode Placement ESD Diode Shunt Capacitance ESD Diode Rdyn ESD Diode Reverse Working Voltage $[internal]Reference Part 
HDMI 2.1 Direct Connect Rate ≤ 6 Gbps (Data)   ≤ 6 Gbps < 25 mm routing length from connector < 0.4 pF < 0.5 Ohm 4.0 V PESD4V0Z1BSF 
HDMI 2.1 Direct Connect Rate > 6Gbps (Data)> 6 Gbps < 25 mm routing length from connector < 0.4 pF < 0.5 Ohm 4.0 V PESD4V0Z1BSF 
HDMI connector HPD/DDC pins   < 25 mm routing length from connector     5.0 V PESD5V0H1BSF 
USB3.2 Gen1/2 Type A≤10 Gbps < 25 mm routing length from connector < 0.35 pF < 0.5 Ohm 3.3 V PESD3V3Z1BSF  

Other Component Selection

Type-C connector Tx/ Rx AC caps (#4)AC caps for Tx, Rx lanesIn order to avoid EOS damage due to shorting between VBUS and adjacent pins, AC cap with voltage rating >= 50 V VBUS maximum voltage rating is required for both Tx and Rx lanes; consider EPR requirement if applicable. The AC cap needs to be next to the connector and followed by ESD diode. Refer to SI PDG for values/placement.

Switching Voltage regulators can show broadband noise in the LTE low band, adding ferrite bead can help in reducing the noise. Ferrite bead selection is based on the current rating of the voltage regulator input pin.ILHB1206ER121V (up to 6A); BLM31SN500SH1 (up to 12 A)

Components for Type-C Interface

The image below indicates various components added on the Type C connector for ESD, EMI and EOS protection. For more details about component selection refer “Other Component Selection (#1 to #7)” table.

Components For Type C Interface

Ferrite Bead for Power and Ground Pins of AC Jack

To prevent EMI noise passing through adapter cable adding ferrite bead at the connector pin can help. For more details refer to AC Jack (#8) details from “Other Component Selection” table.

Ferrite Beads for AC Jack

System Efficient ESD Design (SEED)

PDG Chapter “ESD Diode Selection” serves as a general recommendation for system level ESD protection. To further optimize selection of ESD diode, customers may consider using SEED simulation concept during system design phase. SEED defines an ESD robustness design concept that assures matching between PCB protection components and IC IO behavior during system ESD discharges event. It allows selection of ESD diode which is optimized based on IO characteristics and PCB design. It also promotes early assessment using a simulation to achieve first-time-right PCB design. This design concept applies to hot plug input/output port applications, that includes USB2, USB3, Type-C, DisplayPort, and HDMI.

SEED Block Diagram

SEED simulation deck is available in Advanced Design System (ADS) and HSPICE. Refer to Intel System Efficient ESD Design (SEED) Models User Guide (#702999) for step-by-step simulation guidance. Customers may contact the Intel representative for platform specific SEED Models.

Intel® SEED Analysis Template

EMC Audio

Audio ESD Protection

Audio jack needs to have ESD protection. The ESD diodes need to connect to digital / chassis ground.

Audio Jack ESD Protection

DMIC EMI/ RFI Risk

DMIC clock may have EMI/ RFI risk due to its high-order harmonics.

It is recommended to have stripline routing and a placeholder for an RC filter before being routed in microstrip/ cable to reduce high-frequency harmonics.

The RC value may vary according to the board design to meet the electrical requirements.

Routing Requirements and RC Filter for DMIC Clock

Wi-Fi/WWAN Radios Performance vs. Platform Noise

Noise from multiple aggressors, such as switching power supplies, high-speed digital clocks or data can generate harmonics or broadband noise that interferes with the radio bands on the platform. Noise could couple to the platform antenna hence reducing the radios performance like throughput, latency, and sensitivity by reducing the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR).

This section provides the RF platform noise threshold that can set the baseline for determining if the noise level in the radio bands is tolerable to maintain wireless performance, therefore ensuring the best user experience. To meet the noise requirement, customers could implement the mitigation solutions illustrated in the EMC General Considerations guidelines.

Platform Noise Threshold Recommendation

Each type of noise source has its own characteristic noise profile therefore has its own frequency spectrum that could have a different impact on radio performance. Scrambled data signals for high-speed interfaces (e.g. USB 3.0, DDR5, PCIE) are broadband, covering a wide frequency range and radio band in the GHz range. On the other hand, clock signals are highly periodic and have a relatively narrowband spectrum, which leads to the generation of harmonics. Unlike scrambled data, these harmonics are periodic and predictable.

Noise ProfileWi-Fi In-band Noise Threshold (dBm/100 kHz)WWAN In-band Noise Threshold (dBm/100 kHz)
Narrowband noise (<= 600 kHz Bandwidth)-106-98
Broadband Noise-117-117

The table above shows the recommended noise threshold based on experimental results. By artificially changing the noise profile and level, the figures below represent the throughput and sensitivity impact on Wi-Fi and WWAN. The noise threshold is defined according to the noise level that can ensure radio performance.

Wi-Fi Throughput Degradation by RF Noise Level
WWAN Sensitivity Degradation by RF Noise Level

On-Board Shielding

Platform on-board shielding can be an effective mitigation option against RF interference with Wi-Fi/WWAN/5G antennas. It can help to reduce the platform noise radiation and reduce susceptibility to external RF noise, particularly the memory and SSD.

General On-Board Shielding Consideration

Shielding Ground Contact

To ensure good shielding effectiveness and minimum noise leakage it is critical to have proper electrical contact of the PCB ground layer with the shielding mechanical enclosure, ideally leaving no electrical openings. Poor grounding contact or gaps/seams in the shield can reduce the shielding effectiveness. Also, the size of any aperture and opening in a mechanical shield enclosure needs to be minimized, keeping it smaller than 2.5 mm. A conductive gasket can also be used to ground the shield to the PCB.

The following figure shows a general recommendation for spacing between grounding vias (S). The general recommendation is to use via spacing ≤ λ/6 (e.g., approximately 4 mm for 7.5 GHz). To improve shielding effectiveness, use closer spacing.

On-Board Shield Grounding General Guideline

Thermal and EMI Co-Design Considerations

An integrated thermal and EMI shield co-design solution can be implemented in a system. The thermal/EMI shield solution needs to have proper electrical contact to the PCB ground layer to guarantee adequate shielding effectiveness.

An example of an EMI shield with co-optimized EMC-thermal solution consists of a large metal frame interposer that covers GPU, GDDR devices, GPU voltage regulator, processor, DDR devices and voltage regulator. The metal frame has an electrically conductive interface and connects to the on-board GND pad opening.

Example Implementation of EMC-Thermal Solution
Metal Frame Interposer with Electrically Conductive Interface to Board

EMC Mechanical Considerations

Mechanical design of the system plays a critical role in meeting requirements for EMI, ESD, RFI, RF Immunity and EFT. The broad categories of consideration in mechanical design are chassis design, connector selection and grounding, high speed cable design and grounding.

  • All faces of the chassis should have a conductive EMI coating (in cases where metallic chassis is not used) to provide RF shielding. The sidewalls of the chassis should also have a continuous EMI coating.

  • Conductive contacts between the faces of the chassis are required to reduce the size of the openings along the chassis seams (the faces of the chassis should make continuous electrical contact).

  • Avoid non-conductive coating/paint on screws that are used to secure the motherboard to the chassis or used between chassis faces and expose solder mask on the PCB for the screws to make contact to the PCB ground layers.

  • Large metal parts of the system should be connected to chassis ground at more than one point. Examples of large metal parts include the PCB ground layers, chassis, metal frame of the display, metal casing of the camera modules, FPC cables, etc. Conductive gaskets or screws may be used to tie large metal structures together at multiple contact points.

  • The thermal solution (heat pipe, cold plate) should be grounded to eliminate or reduce any resonance effects that could couple noise in the vicinity of the thermal solution.

  • Refer to Intel White Paper #602554 for further guidelines on the EMI coating thickness and selection criteria, conductive contact between chassis faces and thermal solution grounding.

  • The figures below illustrate the guidance for chassis design considerations:

EMI Coating on Chassis Covers and Sidewalls
Faces of the Chassis should make Continuous Electrical Contact
Thermal Solution Grounding

Type A Connector Selection

  • To minimize RFI, select a type A receptacle shell that has a backside shield with multiple ground contact points to the PCB ground layers.

  • Ensure that the mechanical latches form a ground contact with the plug shell when inserted.

  • Apertures/openings in the receptacle shell should be minimized.

  • The receptacle connectors should be connected to metal chassis or enclosures through grounding fingers, screws, or conductive gaskets

Type C Connector Selection

  • The receptacle shell should have multiple connection points to the PCB ground layers.

  • Apertures in the receptacle should be minimized. If apertures are unavoidable, a maximum aperture size of 1.5 mm is recommended.

  • The receptacle connectors should be connected to metal chassis or enclosures through grounding fingers, screws, or conductive gaskets.

  • The mid-plate in the connector receptacle should be directly connected to system PCB ground layers.

  • Select a connector where the RFI pad in the receptacle has multiple grounding contacts to the receptacle shell.

The following figures illustrate the recommendations for USB Type C connector selection and for further details, refer to the USB Type C Cable and Connector Specification (https://www.usb.org/cable_connector)

Type-C Connector Selection
Conductive Gaskets to Ground IO Connectors to Chassis

Cable Routing and Shielding, Ground Cables to Chassis

Electromagnetic noise can radiate from internal cables carrying high-speed signals causing RF interference or cables can couple noise to sensitive circuits or nets on the PCB and cause RF immunity issues. Internal cables should be well shielded to reduce the noise radiation from it.

The following are key considerations while selecting and designing with internal cables (FPC/FFC):

  • The internal cable should be shielded with either full ground layers on top and bottom, or by using an EMI shielding film (silk screening with silver/copper ink, aluminum/copper film lamination).

  • For the shield to be effective, the shield layer should not be floating as a floating shield does not provide a return current path and may even make the noise radiation worse. To improve the ground contact of the shield, a direct PCB ground or chassis ground connection of the shield is recommended. Multiple grounding points may be needed for long FPCs (typically every 50mm)

  • The routing of the internal cables is also critical to reducing the amount of noise that can couple to the sensitive circuits. For further guidelines on cable routing, refer to Intel White Paper #602554.

  • The figures below illustrate the guidance for internal cable shielding and grounding

Internal Cable Design Criteria for EMI
Direct PCB or Chassis Ground Connection of the Cable Shield

Minimize ESD Chassis Entry Points

It is recommended to design the chassis/system industrial design to minimize ESD entry and thereby improve the system level ESD protection. Following are two examples of ESD entry points and mitigation methods:

  • Example 1: Speaker openings - In systems with metal mesh for the speaker openings, the ESD energy can be diverted to the system ground by connecting the metal mesh to system ground. This will minimize the ESD entry through the speaker lines into the PCB.

  • Example 2: SIM/SD trays - SIM/SD cards are very sensitive to ESD. Avoid any air gaps around the tray that otherwise can lead to ESD entry. Divert ESD into system ground by connecting the metal tray of the SIM/SD to the chassis ground or PCB ground layers.

Minimize ESD Entry Points in the Chassis

Antenna Barricade Technology

The chassis design may not be effective enough at higher frequency bands (6 GHz bands). Noise leakage observed in the seams, slots and between metal-to-metal bonding. Antenna barricade, metal enclosure around antenna, is an effective solution to mitigate RFI noise at platform level by physically and electromagnetically isolating the antenna from potential sources of interference. Experimental data shows ~10 dB noise reduction with antenna barricade. To avoid any opening/leakage EMI gasket material between barricade and chassis can be applied at multiple locations. However, antenna barricade needs to be planned upfront as it is part of chassis design.

Intel has developed a license technology on antenna barricade technology and design. Contact Intel for more information.

Example of Antenna Barricade in Mobile Design

EMC ESD Considerations

ESD Sensitive Net Mitigation

The following net categories may be sensitive to ESD:

  • Processor-Hot or PCH-Hot: *PROCHOT*, *FORCEPR#", *PCHHOT*

  • Reset: *RESET*, *RST*, *RSTB*, *DRAM_RESET*

  • Power-Ok, Power-Good: *PWROK*, *PWRGD*

  • Crystal: XTAL_IN and XTAL_OUT, RTC

System-level ESD issues may be mitigated by one of the following:

  • Routing sensitive nets as stripline.

  • Adding placeholder for decoupling capacitors on the sensitive nets to reduce the ESD level injected into the victim ICs (excluding crystal oscillator). The value of decoupling capacitor varies on different nets and systems. The recommended value is 1-100 nF.

For crystal oscillator, follow the guidelines from “XTAL Topology Guideline” (PCH/IOs chapter), “RTC (Real Time Clock) Topology” (PCH/IOs chapter) and “XTAL Ground Ring Requirement” (Electromagnetic Compatibility Chapter).

ESD Sensitive Net Mitigation

EMC/ RF Reference Documents

PDG Sub-section(s)Document NumberDocument Name
(1) Crystal RF Immunity (2) ESD Diode Selection631030Thunderbolt - Hayden Bridge Collateral

(1) Memory RFI Mitigation Consideration (2) Intel DDR RFI Mitigation (RFIM) Software Feature640438Intel® DDR Memory Radio-Frequency Interference Mitigation (RFIM) Policy Enabling and Validation Technical White Paper
Intel DDR RFI Mitigation (RFIM) Software Feature816192Intel® DDR Radio-Frequency Interference Mitigation (RFIM) Feature Semi-Automation of Table Generation Technical White Paper
Minimize Exposed High Speed I/O Channel Routing610694Intel® WLAN Module Layout Checklist
System Efficient ESD Design702999Intel System Efficient ESD Design (SEED) Models User Guide

VCCPRIM_VNNAON (T3 PCB)

Settings

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1To meet Rpath of <3.5mΩ from VRM to VCCPRIM_VNNAON BGA groups, route VCCPRIM_VNNAON plane on at least three 30um-thick copper layers from VRM output to processor BGA with the following conditions : ► When routing on the top or bottom layer, keep plane width at least 15mm at VRM region & not lesser than 7mm upon approaching BGA region ► When routing on buildup layers (minimum 2 layers), keep plane width at least 10mm at VRM region & not lesser than 6mm upon approaching BGA region VCCPRIM_VNNAON_1
2Short all VCCPRIM_VNNAON BGAs with plane on at least of two 30um-thick copper layersVCCPRIM_VNNAON_2
3VCCPRIM_VNNAON VRM uses pseudo differential sensing to compensate for voltage drops along the power delivery path. The PWR & GND sense lines are connected to BP14 & BP12 BGAs respectivelyVCCPRIM_VNNAON_3
4Short both VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR BGAs (CM16 & CM18) with planeVCCPRIM_VNNAON_4
5Merge both VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR & VCCPRIM_VNNAON power planes using 1 x 0603 1uH (120mΩ max DCR) inductor & 1 x 0603 22uF cap to form an LC-filter with the following conditions : ► Place the LC-filter <1mm distance from or underneath VCCPRIM_VNNAON & VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR BGAs ► Ensure the merging point for both VCCPRIM_VNNAON & VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR planes are <1mm distance from or underneath VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR BGAs Note : Refer diagram for design implementation guidanceVCCPRIM_VNNAON_5
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_1
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_2
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_3
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_4
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_5
Notes
Note
Place VRM bulk cap or additional MLCC caps to keep sense voltage below threshold limit & to fulfill PD requirements
Heighten capacitor effectiveness by placing them from VRM output to package in the following order : 0402 → 0603 → 0805 → Bulk
Establish robust return path for decoupling capacitor by minimizing the distance between power & ground via pairs as well as placing the via pairs as close as possible to the capacitor pads
When placing capacitors, align their pads to the current path flowing from VR to package
Customers can choose capacitors of any form factor provided the caps meet the recommended parasitic capacitance.
Component PlacementForm FactorValueQuantityNoteReference Design
Primary Side7343330uF1Place bulk cap near to VRM outputVCCPRIM_VNNAON_6
Primary Side060322uF6Place caps near to VRM outputVCCPRIM_VNNAON_6
Secondary Side060322uF6Place caps near to VRM outputVCCPRIM_VNNAON_7
Secondary Side060347uF1Place 1 x 0603 47uF cap under processor die shadow of VCCPRIM_VNNAON BGAs
Secondary side060347uF2Place 2 x 0603 47uF caps <1mm from VCCPRIM_VNNAON PTH located underneath BGAVCCPRIM_VNNAON_8
Secondary Side060322uF5Place 5 x 0603 22uF caps <10mm from package edge. Make sure PWR-GND PTH pair is placed very close to cap terminals VCCPRIM_VNNAON_8
Secondary Side040210uF4Place 4 x 0402 10uF caps underneath BGA or <1mm from package edge. Make sure PWR-GND PTH pair is placed very close to cap terminals VCCPRIM_VNNAON_8
Secondary Side060322uF1Pair 1 x 0603 22uF VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR cap with 1 x 0603 1uH (120mΩ max DCR) inductor <1mm from or underneath VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR BGAs to form an LC-filterVCCPRIM_VNNAON_8
Secondary Side06031 uH_120mΩ DCR1Merge both VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR & VCCPRIM_VNNAON power planes using 1 x 0603 1uH (120mΩ max DCR) inductor & 1 x 0603 22uF cap to form an LC-filter with the following conditions : ► Place the LC-filter <1mm distance from or underneath VCCPRIM_VNNAON & VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR BGAs ► Ensure the merging point for both VCCPRIM_VNNAON & VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR planes are <1mm distance from or underneath VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR BGAs VCCPRIM_VNNAON_8
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_6
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_7
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_8

VCCPRIM_VNNAON (T4 PCB)

Settings

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1Design at least two solid and wide power planes as continuous current path from VR output all the way to BGAs. Advise to use 30um copper thickness layer for these two main routing layers. Ensure solid ground reference plane in nearby layers. Connect BGA pins when possibleVCCPRIM_VNNAON_1, VCCPRIM_VNNAON_2
2The VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR rail require very clean supply, isolated from VCCPRIM_VNNAON in package and advise merge back to VCCPRIM_VNNAON only on board secondary side through an LC filter. VCCPRIM_VNNAON has two power pins CM16 and CM18.VCCPRIM_VNNAON_3
3VCCPRIM_VNNAON VRM uses differential sensing BP14 (SENSE_VCCPRIM_VNNAON) and BP12(SENSE_VSS_VCCPRIM_VNNAON).
4Maximum Rpath from VRM output inductor location to VCCPRIM_VNNAON BGA groups is 3.5mOhm.
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_1
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_2
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_3
Notes
Note
Place VRM bulk cap or additional MLCC caps to keep sense voltage below threshold limit & to fulfill PD requirements
Heighten capacitor effectiveness by placing them from VRM output to package in the following order : 0402 → 0603 → 0805 → Bulk
Establish robust return path for decoupling capacitor by minimizing the distance between power & ground via pairs as well as placing the via pairs as close as possible to the capacitor pads
When placing capacitors, align their pads to the current path flowing from VR to package
Customers can choose capacitors of any form factor provided the caps meet the recommended parasitic capacitance.
Component PlacementForm FactorValueQuantityNoteReference Design
Primary Side7343330uF1Place near VRM. ESR = 4.5 mΩVCCPRIM_VNNAON_4
Primary/Secondary Side060322uF12Place near VRMVCCPRIM_VNNAON_4, VCCPRIM_VNNAON_5
Secondary side060347uF3Place 3 x 0603 47uF caps under VCCPRIM_VNNAON BGA region. One of the cap place need to place in processor die area.VCCPRIM_VNNAON_5
Secondary Side060322uF5Place 5 x 0603 22uF with distance <10mm from Package edge. VCCPRIM_VNNAON_5
Secondary Side040210uF4Place 4 x 0402 10uF caps under VCCPRIM_VNNAON BGA region.VCCPRIM_VNNAON_5
Secondary Side060322uF1Capacitor of LC filterVCCPRIM_VNNAON_5
Secondary Side0402/06031 uH_120mΩ DCR1Inductor of LC filter. Electrical requirement of the inductor: rated current > 200mA, DCR < 0.12ΩVCCPRIM_VNNAON_5
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_4

VCCPRIM_IO (T3 PCB)

Settings

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1Route VCCPRIM_IO power plane from VR output inductor to the BGA on Layer 1, Layer 6 and Layer 8. Adjacent layer from VCCPRIM_IO power plane should be ground.VCCPRIM_IO_1
2VCCPRIM_IO_FLTR should be merged with VCCPRIM_IO after LC filter on Layer 8VCCPRIM_IO_1
3VCCPRIM_IO VRM uses differential sensing. The power sense line is connected to SENSE_VCCPRIM_IO BGA(DF8) and ground sense line connected to SENSE_VSS_VCCPRIM_IO(DF9)VCCPRIM_IO_2
4The SVID 1.25 V supply for pull up resistors should be sourced from VCCPRIM_IO_OUT_SVID BGA EP5.
VCCPRIM_IO_1
VCCPRIM_IO_2
Notes
Note
Place VRM bulk cap or additional MLCC caps to keep sense voltage below threshold limit & to fulfill PD requirements
Heighten capacitor effectiveness by placing them from VRM to package in the following order : 0402 → 0603 → 0805 →Bulk
Establish robust return path for decoupling capacitor by minimizing the distance between power & ground via pairs as well as placing the via pairs as close as possible to the capacitor pads
Align capacitor pads to the current path flowing from VR to package
Customers can choose capacitors of any form factor if the capacitors meet the recommended parasitic capacitance.
Component PlacementForm FactorValueQuantityNoteReference Design
Primary Side080547uF4Place near the VCCPRIM_IO VRM outputVCCPRIM_IO_3,VCCPRIM_IO_4
Secondary side 060322 uF3Place right below the VCCPRIM_IO BGA VCCPRIM_IO_3,VCCPRIM_IO_4
Secondary side040210 uF3Place right below the VCCPRIM_IO BGAVCCPRIM_IO_3,VCCPRIM_IO_4
Secondary side 02011uF4Place right below the VCCPRIM_IO BGA VCCPRIM_IO_3,VCCPRIM_IO_4
Secondary side (Inductor)06031 uH1Inductor component of the LC filter from VCCPRIM_IO_FLTR rail with ESR = 350mOVCCPRIM_IO_3,VCCPRIM_IO_4
Secondary side0402/060322 uF1Decoupling capacitor placed on VCCPRIM_IO_FLTR rail for LC filtering purposeVCCPRIM_IO_3,VCCPRIM_IO_4
Secondary side02011uF1Place right below the VCCPRIM_IO_FLTR BGAVCCPRIM_IO_3,VCCPRIM_IO_4

VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC

Settings

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1Route the VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC, VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_FLTRA and VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_FLTRB on Layer 4 & Layer 6, with immediate ground reference. VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_FLTRA should be merged with VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC after LC filter on Layer 1.VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_1
VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_1
Notes
Note
Power and ground via pairs should be placed close to capacitor pads to provide proper vertical connections when placing capacitor on the secondary side.
Customers can choose capacitors of any form factor if the capacitors meet the recommended parasitic capacitance.
Component PlacementForm FactorValueQuantityNoteReference Design
Primary side (Inductor)0805 / 06031uH1Inductor component of the LC filter from VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC rail to VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_FLTRA rail. It must meet electrical requirements: max DCR < 100mOhm and rated current >200 mA.VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_2
Primary side060322uF2Decoupling capacitor(C1,C2) placed on VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_FLTRA rail for LC filtering purpose.VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_2
Secondary side0201Placeholder1Place C3 under VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_FLTRA BGAs.VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_2
Secondary side0603Placeholder1Place C4 under VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_FLTRB BGAs. VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_2
Secondary side0201Placeholder1Place C5 under VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_FLTRB BGAs.VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_2
Secondary side0402 / 0201Placeholder1Place C6 under VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC BGAsVCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_2
VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_2

Settings (Internal)

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1Route the VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC, VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_FLTRA and VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_FLTRB on Layer 4 & Layer 6, with immediate ground reference. VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_FLTRA should be merged with VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC after LC filter on Layer 1. VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_1
VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_1
Notes
Note
Power and ground via pairs should be placed close to capacitor pads to provide proper vertical connections when placing capacitor on the secondary side.
Customers can choose capacitors of any form factor if the capacitors meet the recommended parasitic capacitance.
Component PlacementForm FactorValueSoldered DownISC SocketPPV SocketNoteReference Design
Primary side (Inductor)0805 / 06031 uH111Inductor component of the LC filter from VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC rail to VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_FLTRA rail. It must meet electrical requirements: max DCR < 100mOhm and rated current >200 mA.VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_2
Primary side060322 uF222Decoupling capacitor (C1, C2) placed on VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_FLTRA rail for LC filtering purpose.VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_2
Secondary side0201Placeholder111Place C3 under VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_FLTRA.VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_2
Secondary side0603Placeholder111Place C4 under VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_FLTRB BGAs.VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_2
Secondary side0201Placeholder111Place C5 under VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_FLTRB BGAs.VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_2
Secondary side0402 / 0201Placeholder111Place C6 under VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC BGAs.VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_2
VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_2

VCCRTC_PROC

Settings

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1Require 1 layer of VCCRTC_PROC plane from vrm to board pin with immediate GND reference on one of the adjacent layers. Refer to reference design image for design implementation.VCCRTC_PROC_1
VCCRTC_PROC_1
Notes
Note
Customers can choose capacitors of any form factor if the capacitors meet the recommended parasitic capacitance.

VCCRTC_PROC_2

VCCGT(H404/T3/0.8mm PCB)

Settings

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1Design solid planes for a continuous current flow path from VR output to BGA. Please see reference image as an example of feasible placement. VCCGT_H404_T3_0.8mm_1
2Adjacent solid ground to power planes for good return path.
3Sense pins routed as differential pair to VR. Avoid routing adjacent to noisy power plane and have adjacent solid ground plane for good return path.
VCCGT_H404_T3_0.8mm_1
Notes
Note
1. Smaller capacitors should be placed closest to the package. For example: Package -> 0201 -> 0402 ->0603 ->Bulk -> VR.
2. For bottom layer capacitor placement, place 0201, 0402, 0603 capacitors directly under the package and cannot be placed at the edge.
3. Capacitor recommendation based on VR solution with 150 kHz VR bandwidth or 600 kHz switching frequency, assuming BW=1/4 of Fsw.
4. Align capacitor pads along current flow path from VR to package. Make sure decoupling capacitors have power/ ground via pairs connected as close as possible to the capacitors pads.
5. Use MLCC components with 6.3 V voltage rating.
6. Please refer to acoustic noise mitigation technical advisory document #575216 for more details.
Component PlacementForm FactorValueQuantityNoteReference Design
Primary side7343330 uF1Recommended capacitor ESR = 4.5mOhm with 2.5V voltage rating.VCCGT_H404_T3_0.8mm_2
Primary side7343Placeholder1VCCGT_H404_T3_0.8mm_2
Secondary side040210 uF15VCCGT_H404_T3_0.8mm_3
Secondary side060322uF10VCCGT_H404_T3_0.8mm_3
Secondary side0402Placeholder3VCCGT_H404_T3_0.8mm_3
Secondary side0603Placeholder2VCCGT_H404_T3_0.8mm_3
VCCGT_H404_T3_0.8mm_2
VCCGT_H404_T3_0.8mm_3

Settings (Internal)

IndexDesign NoteReference Design

VCC_CORE_H484_T3_0.8mm_&_0.9mm_3

VCC_CORE(H12Xe/T3/0.8mm & 0.9mm PCB)

Settings

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1Design solid planes for a continuous current flow path from VR output to BGA. Please see reference image as an example of feasible placement. VCC_CORE_H12Xe_T3_0.8mm_&_0.9mm_1
2Adjacent solid ground to power planes for good return path.
3Sense pins routed as differential pair to VR. Avoid routing adjacent to noisy power plane and have adjacent solid ground plane for good return path.
VCC_CORE_H12Xe_T3_0.8mm_&_0.9mm_1
Notes
Note
1. Smaller capacitors should be placed closest to the package. For example: Package -> 0201 -> 0402 ->0603 ->Bulk -> VR.
2. For bottom layer capacitor placement, place 0201, 0402, 0603 capacitors directly under the package and cannot be placed at the edge.
3. Capacitor recommendation based on VR solution with 150 kHz VR bandwidth or 600 kHz switching frequency, assuming BW=1/4 of Fsw.
4. Align capacitor pads along current flow path from VR to package. Make sure decoupling capacitors have power/ ground via pairs connected as close as possible to the capacitors pads.
5. Use MLCC components with 6.3 V voltage rating.
6. Please refer to acoustic noise mitigation technical advisory document #575216 for more details.
Component PlacementForm FactorValueQuantityNoteReference Design
Primary side7343330 uF2Recommended capacitor ESR = 4.5mOhm with 2.5V voltage rating.VCC_CORE_H12Xe_T3_0.8mm_&_0.9mm_2
Primary side7343Placeholder1VCC_CORE_H12Xe_T3_0.8mm_&_0.9mm_2
Secondary side02011 uF5Place beneath BGA.VCC_CORE_H12Xe_T3_0.8mm_&_0.9mm_3
Secondary side040210 uF10Place beneath BGA.VCC_CORE_H12Xe_T3_0.8mm_&_0.9mm_3
Secondary side060322 uF3Place beneath BGA.VCC_CORE_H12Xe_T3_0.8mm_&_0.9mm_3
Secondary side0201Placeholder7VCC_CORE_H12Xe_T3_0.8mm_&_0.9mm_3
Secondary side0603Placeholder9VCC_CORE_H12Xe_T3_0.8mm_&_0.9mm_3
VCC_CORE_H12Xe_T3_0.8mm_&_0.9mm_2

DDR5 Device Decoupling

Small Outline Dual In-line Memory Module (SODIMM)

DDR5 SODIMM comes with PMIC/ VR and decoupling on the module card itself, hence no additional decoupling guidelines are required. Nevertheless the source supply to the DDR5 SODIMM needs to follow the JEDEC/ vendor specification sheet.

DDR5 SODIMM comes with PMIC/ VR and decoupling on the module card itself, hence no additional decoupling guidelines are required. Nevertheless the source supply to the DDR5 SODIMM needs to follow the JEDEC/ vendor specification sheet.

LPDDR5/x Device Decoupling

Memory Down Decoupling Config: 4X32

Description: LPDDR5x x32 memory down PI solution guidance with eDVFSC enabled on the platform.

eDVFSC requires an independent VDD2L rail on the platform. If the eDVFSC support is not desired on the platform, customers can short/merge DRAM VDD2L ball with the VDD2H rail. Customers should consult the DRAM vendors for design guidance on the merged VDD2H/VDD2L rail..

Notes
Note
TYPE-4 (2-x-2+) DRAM power rail layer assignment is provided in LPDDR5x_TYPE4_1
TYPE-3 10L DRAM power rail layer assignment is provided in LPDDR5x_TYPE3_1
VSS referencing is recommended for all the Memory power rails
Information provided here is only for guidance. Customers are responsible for meeting all JEDEC SPECS on the Memory power rails
Voltage RailCapacitor Form Factor and ValueQuantityNotesReference Design
VDD2H0201, 1 uF164 caps per DRAM, 1 per side close to VDD2H BGAs. Customers may adjust the capacitor quantity/ form factor/ value to meet the JEDEC spec.LPDDR5x_TYPE4_2, LPDDR5x_TYPE3_2
VDD2H0402, 10 uF41 cap per DRAM. Customers may adjust the capacitor quantity/ form factor/ value to meet the JEDEC spec.LPDDR5x_TYPE4_2, LPDDR5x_TYPE3_2
VDDQ0201, 1 uF164 caps per DRAM, 1 per each corner close to VDDQ BGAs. Customers may adjust the capacitor quantity/ form factor/ value to meet the JEDEC spec.LPDDR5x_TYPE4_3, LPDDR5x_TYPE3_3
VDDQ0402, 10 uF41 cap per DRAM. Customers may adjust the capacitor quantity/ form factor/ value to meet the JEDEC spec.LPDDR5x_TYPE4_3, LPDDR5x_TYPE3_3
VDD10201, 1 uF164 caps per DRAM, 1 per each VDD1 BGA. Customers may adjust the capacitor quantity/ form factor/ value to meet the JEDEC spec.LPDDR5x_TYPE4_4, LPDDR5x_TYPE3_4
VDD10402, 10 uF41 cap per DRAM. Customers may adjust the capacitor quantity/ form factor/ value to meet the JEDEC spec.LPDDR5x_TYPE4_4, LPDDR5x_TYPE3_4
VDD2L0201, 1uF164 cap per DRAM, 1 per each corner close to VDD2L BGA's Customers may adjust the capacitor quantity/ form factor/ value to meet the JEDEC spec.LPDDR5x_TYPE4_5, LPDDR5x_TYPE3_5
VDD2L0402, 10uF41 cap per DRAM. Customers may adjust the capacitor quantity/ form factor/ value to meet the JEDEC spec.LPDDR5x_TYPE4_5, LPDDR5x_TYPE3_5
LPDDR5x_TYPE4_1
LPDDR5x_TYPE4_2
LPDDR5x_TYPE4_3
LPDDR5x_TYPE4_4
LPDDR5x_TYPE4_5
LPDDR5x_TYPE3_1
LPDDR5x_TYPE3_2
LPDDR5x_TYPE3_3
LPDDR5x_TYPE3_4
LPDDR5x_TYPE3_5

LPCAMM2 E1 Connector

LPCAMM2 E1 Module

Description: LPCAMM2 E1 module has a configurable VDDQ rail option i.e. VDDQ rail can be sourced from on module PMIC or from the Motherboard VRM. This section provides routing recommendations for using Motherboard VDDQ VRM shared with the SOC.

A shared VDDQ rail between the SOC and LPCAMM2 E1 module is required to support eDVFSQ feature. A shared VDDQ rail between the SOC and LPCAMM2 E1 module is required to support speeds above 7467 MT/s.

Notes
Note
Information provided here is only for guidance. Customers are responsible for meeting all LPCAMM2 E1 connector JEDEC SPECS.
VSS referencing is recommended for the VDDQ power rail.
Voltage RailCapacitor Form Factor and ValueQuantityNotesReference Design
VDDQ0603, PH2Customers may adjust the capacitor quantity/ form factor/ value to meet the JEDEC spec.LPCAMM2_E1_1
LPCAMM2_E1_1

RCOMP

RCOMP Connection Diagram
Example RCOMP with GND Shield
RCOMP General Guidelines
Detail
Trace width 75 um with min trace spacing 100 um.
Max total length on board = 9 mm. Max number of vias 1.
GND shield to any high speed IO with VSS trace/ strip. This is not required if the adjacent signal is another RCOMP signal. PTH vias are required to be punched from this GND shield to the referenced GND plane.
GND reference required. Noisy or switching references should be avoided.
Board external resistor size = 0201 (recommended).
Strongly recommended to follow breakout board placement.
RCOMP Configuration

RCOMP (Internal)

RCOMP Connection Diagram
Example_RCOMP_with_GND_shield
RCOMP_with_floating
RCOMP General Guidelines
Detail
Trace width 75um with min trace spacing 100um.
Max total length on board = 9 mm. Max number of vias 1.
GND shield to any high speed IO with VSS trace/ strip. This is not required if the adjacent signal is another RCOMP signal. PTH vias are required to be punched from this GND shield to the referenced GND plane.
GND reference required. Noisy or switching references should be avoided.
Board external resistor size=0201(recommended).
Strongly recommended to follow breakout board placement.
RCOMP Configuration
InterfaceSignal NameBoard RTerm (Ohm)Max Board DC resistance (Ohm)Tolerance (+/-)%Connection on other SideMax Board Parasitic Capacitance (pF)Resistor StuffingRouting Guide
CNViCNV_RCOMP2000.11GND1.5Mandatorya) TIU/SV/DV testing need to apply 200 Ohm +/- "0.1"% tolerance. refer to the RCOMP General Guidelines.
DisplayDDI_RCOMP1500.11GND1.5Mandatoryrefer to the RCOMP General Guidelines.
Type CPCD_TC_2_GRCOMP00.10N/A1.5Floatinga) Leave it floating and no connect after PTH via refer to the RCOMP_with_floating picture and apply the RCOMP General Guidelines.
Type CPCD_TC_2_GRCOMPV00.10N/A1.5Floatinga) Leave it floating and no connect after PTH via refer to the RCOMP_with_floating picture and apply the RCOMP General Guidelines.
